lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: ACT Test Basics & Overview
lessons.content:
Understanding the ACT Test structure, scoring system, timing strategies, and question types is essential before diving into specific content. The ACT consists of four required sections—English, Math, Reading, and Science—plus an optional Writing section. This lesson will give you a complete overview of the test format, teach you how scores work, and provide strategic insights to help you maximize your performance on test day.

1. Test Structure and Format

The ACT is a standardized test used by colleges for admissions decisions. Unlike the SAT, the ACT tests more straightforward knowledge and has a Science section. The test is divided into four required sections and one optional section, with a total testing time of about 3 hours (or 3.5 hours with Writing).

English Section: 45 Minutes, 75 Questions

The English section tests grammar, punctuation, sentence structure, and rhetorical skills across five passages. You'll have approximately 45 seconds per question. Questions test conventions of standard English (grammar and usage), production of writing (strategy and organization), and knowledge of language (style and tone). This section appears first on the test, so starting strong is crucial for building confidence.

Math Section: 60 Minutes, 60 Questions

The Math section covers pre-algebra, elementary algebra, intermediate algebra, coordinate geometry, plane geometry, and trigonometry. You have one minute per question on average. A reference sheet with basic formulas is provided, but memorizing key formulas will save time. Calculators are permitted (and highly recommended) for this entire section.

Reading Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Reading section includes four passages: Prose Fiction/Literary Narrative, Social Science, Humanities, and Natural Science. Each passage has 10 questions. You'll have about 8 minutes and 45 seconds per passage, so time management is critical. Questions test your ability to determine main ideas, locate details, understand sequences, make comparisons, comprehend cause-effect relationships, determine word meaning, and analyze author's voice and method.

Science Section: 35 Minutes, 40 Questions

The Science section tests interpretation, analysis, evaluation, reasoning, and problem-solving skills through data representation, research summaries, and conflicting viewpoints passages. Don't worry—you don't need advanced science knowledge! The section primarily tests your ability to read graphs, charts, and tables, and apply scientific reasoning. Most students find this section challenging due to the pace (about 53 seconds per question).

2. Scoring System and What Scores Mean

Understanding how the ACT is scored helps you set realistic goals and track your progress. The ACT uses a scaled scoring system from 1-36, and there's no penalty for wrong answers, so you should always guess if you're running out of time.

How Scores Are Calculated

Each section (English, Math, Reading, Science) receives a scaled score from 1-36 based on the number of questions you answer correctly (your raw score). These four section scores are then averaged to create your Composite Score, which is the most important number for college admissions. The composite is rounded to the nearest whole number—for example, if your four section scores are 28, 30, 26, and 32, your composite is (28+30+26+32)/4 = 29.

What's a Good Score?

The national average composite score is around 20-21. A score of 24 puts you in approximately the 75th percentile, meaning you scored higher than 75% of test-takers. Competitive colleges typically want scores above 27, while highly selective schools (Ivy League, top liberal arts colleges) generally expect 32-36. However, "good" depends on your target schools—research the average ACT scores for admitted students at colleges you're interested in.

Subscores and STEM Score

In addition to section scores, you'll receive subscores (1-18 scale) for specific skill areas like "Production of Writing" in English or "Integrating Essential Skills" in Math. You'll also see a STEM score, which averages your Math and Science scores. While colleges primarily focus on your composite and individual section scores, subscores can help identify specific areas for improvement.

Superscoring

Many colleges practice superscoring, which means they take your highest section scores across multiple test dates and recalculate a new composite. For example, if you score English 28, Math 30, Reading 25, Science 27 on Test 1, then English 26, Math 32, Reading 28, Science 26 on Test 2, your superscore would combine the best from each: 28, 32, 28, 27 = composite 28.75, rounded to 29. Check whether your target colleges superscore—this policy encourages retaking the ACT to improve individual sections.

3. General Test-Taking Strategies

Success on the ACT requires more than content knowledge—you need effective time management, strategic guessing, and stress management skills. These universal strategies apply across all four sections.

Always Answer Every Question

The ACT has no guessing penalty—wrong answers don't count against you. This means you should NEVER leave a question blank. If you're running out of time, quickly bubble in an answer for every remaining question. Statistically, random guessing gives you about a 20-25% chance of being correct, which is better than 0%!

Pace Yourself and Use a Watch

Time pressure is one of the ACT's biggest challenges. Wear a watch (analog watches are best since digital devices aren't allowed) and set checkpoints. For example, in Reading, you should finish passage 1 by minute 8, passage 2 by minute 17, passage 3 by minute 26, and passage 4 by minute 35. Don't spend too long on any single question—if you're stuck after 30-45 seconds, make your best guess, circle it in the test booklet, and move on. You can return if time permits.

Answer Easy Questions First

Not all questions are created equal. Some are straightforward, while others require complex reasoning. Within each section, scan for "quick points"—questions you can answer confidently in 20-30 seconds. Rack up these easy points first, then tackle harder questions with your remaining time. This strategy maximizes your score even if time runs out.

Process of Elimination

When you're unsure of the correct answer, use process of elimination. Cross out answers you know are wrong in your test booklet, then guess among remaining choices. Eliminating even one wrong answer improves your odds from 20% to 25% (for 4-choice questions) or 25% to 33% (for 3-choice questions). Often you can eliminate 2-3 choices, giving you a strong chance of guessing correctly.

4. Test Day Preparation and Logistics

Your performance on test day depends not only on preparation but also on practical considerations like what to bring, how to manage stress, and what to expect at the testing center. Being well-prepared logistically helps you focus entirely on the test itself.

What to Bring

Mandatory items: your admission ticket (printed from your ACT account) and an acceptable photo ID (school ID, driver's license, or passport). Recommended items: several sharpened No. 2 pencils with erasers, an approved calculator with fresh batteries, a watch (not a smartwatch), snacks and water for breaks, and layered clothing in case the room is too hot or cold. Do NOT bring: cell phones, smartwatches, prohibited calculators, reference materials, or scratch paper (you can use the test booklet).

Night Before and Morning Of

The night before: review a few key formulas or grammar rules, but don't cram—it's more important to get 8 hours of sleep. Pack your backpack with everything you'll need. Set multiple alarms. The morning of: eat a substantial, protein-rich breakfast (avoid sugary foods that cause energy crashes). Arrive at the test center by 7:45 AM for an 8:00 AM start—latecomers aren't admitted. Use the bathroom before testing begins, as breaks are limited.

Managing Test Anxiety

Feeling nervous is normal, but excessive test anxiety can hurt your performance. Practice deep breathing techniques: inhale slowly for 4 counts, hold for 4 counts, exhale for 4 counts. During the test, if you feel overwhelmed, close your eyes for 10 seconds, take a deep breath, and refocus. Remember: you can retake the ACT—this one test doesn't define you. Confidence comes from preparation, so thorough practice with realistic timed tests is your best defense against anxiety.

After the Test

Scores are typically released 2-8 weeks after your test date (check your ACT account for the exact release date). You can send your scores to colleges for free on test day (list up to 4 schools), or pay later to send additional score reports. Many students take the ACT 2-3 times to improve their composite score—each attempt gives you new experience and insights. Review your score report carefully to identify weak areas, then create a targeted study plan for your next attempt.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The ACT has four sections: English (45 min, 75 Q), Math (60 min, 60 Q), Reading (35 min, 40 Q), Science (35 min, 40 Q)
  • ✓Scores range from 1-36 per section; your Composite is the average of all four sections
  • ✓There's no guessing penalty—ALWAYS answer every question, even if you have to guess
  • ✓Time management is crucial: use a watch, set checkpoints, and don't spend too long on any question
  • ✓Many colleges superscore—taking the ACT multiple times can improve your composite
  • ✓Test day essentials: admission ticket, photo ID, No. 2 pencils, approved calculator, watch

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.1 - Building Complete Sentences
lessons.content:
Sentence structure questions make up 15-20% of the ACT English Test—that's 11-15 questions per test! To master these questions, you must understand how to identify and properly combine clauses, fix fragments, and avoid comma splices.

1. Clauses, Phrases, and Fragments

Independent Clauses

  • An independent clause can stand as a sentence by itself
    • Always has a subject and a verb
    • Read the sentence out loud—if you can stop talking at the end, it's an independent clause
    • Examples: "The dog chased its tail" / "He picked it up"

Dependent Clauses

  • A dependent clause cannot stand alone as a complete sentence
    • Most often created by adding a subordinating conjunction to the front
    • Common subordinating conjunctions: after, although, as, because, before, even though, if, in order to, once, since, that, though, unless, until, when, whenever, where, whether, while, whatever
    • Examples: "While the dog chased its tail..." / "Because he picked it up..."
  • How to identify: If you feel like you need to keep talking after reading it, it's dependent
    • Cover the first word and read the rest—if it becomes a complete sentence, the original was a dependent clause
    • If it's still incomplete after covering the first word, it's a phrase

Phrases

  • A phrase lacks a subject or verb or both
    • Does not express a complete thought and can never stand alone
    • Provides additional descriptive information in a sentence
    • Examples: "Chasing its tail..." / "Excited to open up his present..."
    • All missing the subject—we don't know who is doing the action

Sentence Fragments

  • A sentence fragment is missing a subject or verb or both
    • Cannot stand by itself as a complete sentence
    • Usually sounds plain wrong when you read it aloud
    • Incorrect: "The student running to get to class on time" (missing verb)
    • Correct: "The student running to get to class on time dropped her water bottle"

2. Five Types of Compound Sentences

  • On the ACT, multiple clauses must always appear as one of these 5 types
    • The ACT tests these rules constantly—memorize all 5!
    • Answer choices that "sound good" but break these rules are wrong

Type 1: Two Separate Independent Clauses with Periods

  • Structure: Independent clause + period + Independent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs. Andrew loves cats."

Type 2: Comma + FANBOYS Joining 2 Independent Clauses

  • Structure: Independent clause + comma + FANBOYS + Independent clause
    • FANBOYS = For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So (memorize these!)
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs, and Andrew loves cats."
    • CRITICAL: Must have BOTH the comma AND the FANBOYS word

Type 3: Semicolon Between 2 Independent Clauses

  • Structure: Independent clause + semicolon + Independent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs; Andrew loves cats."
    • On the ACT, a semicolon functions the same as a period
    • Both sides MUST be independent clauses

Type 4: Dependent Clause Followed by Independent Clause (Comma)

  • Structure: Dependent clause + comma + Independent clause
    • Example: "While Mary loves dogs, Andrew loves cats."
    • When dependent clause comes BEFORE independent, use a comma

Type 5: Independent Clause Straight Into Dependent Clause (No Comma)

  • Structure: Independent clause + no comma + Dependent clause
    • Example: "Mary loves dogs while Andrew loves cats."
    • When independent clause comes BEFORE dependent, NO comma

3. Comma Splices

  • A comma splice joins two independent clauses with only a comma—this is ALWAYS incorrect
    • Incorrect: "It is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red, they are actually colorblind"
    • A comma by itself CANNOT join two independent clauses
    • Most common error students make with sentence structure

Five Ways to Fix a Comma Splice

  • Use the 5 compound sentence rules to fix comma splices
    • Rule #1 (Period): "...color red. They are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #2 (Comma + FANBOYS): "...color red, but they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #3 (Semicolon): "...color red; they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #4 (Dependent → Independent): "While it is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red, they are actually colorblind."
    • Rule #5 (Independent → Dependent): "It is believed that bulls are enraged by the color red though they are actually colorblind."

4. Spotting and Solving Sentence Structure Questions

How to Identify Sentence Structure Questions

  • Punctuation variations in answer choices
    • Periods, semicolons, commas, and FANBOYS appear in different positions
    • If you see these variations, it's a sentence structure question
  • Subject or verb forms vary between choices
    • One choice says "drove" while another says "driving"
    • Some choices have subjects/verbs, others don't
    • Watch for comma splices in these questions

Three-Step Approach to Sentence Structure Questions

  • Step 1: Find where the sentence is being "split"
    • Look for the punctuation point in the underlined portion
  • Step 2: Look left and right of the split point
    • Identify whether each side is independent, dependent, or a phrase
    • Read each side separately to test if it can stand alone
  • Step 3: Apply the sentence structure rules
    • Use the 5 compound sentence types to determine the correct answer
    • Eliminate choices that break the rules

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Independent clauses can stand alone as complete sentences, while dependent clauses (starting with subordinating conjunctions) and phrases cannot—test by reading aloud to see if you can stop talking at the end
  • ✓There are exactly 5 ways to combine clauses correctly: (1) period between independent clauses, (2) comma + FANBOYS between independent clauses, (3) semicolon between independent clauses, (4) dependent + comma + independent, (5) independent + no comma + dependent
  • ✓A comma by itself CANNOT join two independent clauses—this creates a comma splice which is always incorrect—fix using one of the 5 compound sentence rules
  • ✓To solve sentence structure questions: (1) find the split point, (2) identify whether each side is independent, dependent, or a phrase, (3) apply the appropriate rule—look for punctuation variations in answer choices as clues

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Essential Comma Rules
lessons.content:
Commas are the most common punctuation on the ACT English Test, appearing in 15-20 questions per test. To master comma questions, you need to understand the 4 types of commas and when each one should be used.

1. The Four Types of Commas

  • The ACT tests exactly 4 comma rules—master these and you'll handle every comma question
    • Each type has a specific purpose and can't be substituted with another
    • Understanding when to use each type is critical for avoiding comma errors

Type 1: Comma + FANBOYS

  • Use a comma and a FANBOYS word to join two independent clauses
    • FANBOYS = For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So
    • Example: "My alarm clock did not go off this morning, so I arrived late at school"
    • Both sides must be independent clauses (complete sentences)

Type 2: Dependent Clause Followed by Independent Clause

  • When a dependent clause comes before an independent clause, use a comma to separate them
    • Example: "While electronic music has become very popular, many people still prefer classic rock"
    • The dependent clause starts with subordinating conjunctions like while, although, because, if
    • This is from Chapter 1's Rule #4 for compound sentences

Type 3: Unnecessary Information

  • Commas separate unnecessary information from the rest of the sentence
    • Information is unnecessary if you can remove it without fundamentally changing the sentence's meaning
    • Unnecessary information can be as short as one word or as long as a lengthy phrase
    • Example: "Mrs. Ellison, who is known for giving pop quizzes, is my least favorite teacher"
    • Example: "The basketball team, though, did not mount a comeback this week"

Type 4: Listing

  • Use commas when listing more than two items or with multiple adjectives modifying the same noun
    • Example with list: "The group ordered coconut shrimp, hot wings, and onion rings"
    • Example with adjectives: "The old, limping dog still managed to complete the 3-mile hike"
    • Use commas between all items in a series, including before the final "and" or "or"

2. Unnecessary Information Commas

  • The most common comma type on the ACT separates unnecessary information
    • Information is unnecessary if removing it doesn't fundamentally change the sentence's meaning
    • Unnecessary information can appear before a comma, after a comma, or between two commas
    • After removing unnecessary information, what remains must still be a complete sentence

The "Crossing-Out" Trick

  • To test if information is unnecessary, cross it out and read what remains
    • If the sentence is still complete and makes sense, the information is unnecessary
    • If the sentence becomes incomplete or loses critical meaning, the information is necessary (no commas)
    • Example: "The wooden beam, set at an angle, created an optical illusion"
    • Cross out "set at an angle" → "The wooden beam created an optical illusion" (still complete!)

Necessary vs. Unnecessary Information

  • Determining if information is truly unnecessary requires careful reading
    • Correct (necessary): "The dresses that need to be hemmed are hanging in the closet"
    • Without "that need to be hemmed," we don't know which specific dresses
    • Correct (unnecessary): "Judith, who went to fashion school, designs dresses for a living"
    • We already know who designs dresses (Judith), so the fashion school detail is extra

The Names Rule

  • The ACT loves testing comma usage with names—you'll see at least one question on this
    • If the identifier is NOT specific to one person (friend, teacher, physicist), the name is necessary—no commas
    • Example: "My friend Kelly recently moved to London" (I have multiple friends, so Kelly is necessary)
    • If the identifier IS specific to one person (best friend, youngest sister, CEO), the name is unnecessary—use commas
    • Example: "My best friend, Andrew, is a certified scuba diver" (I have only one best friend)

"That" vs. "Which" Phrases

  • Phrases starting with that never get commas—phrases starting with which always get commas
    • "That" phrases are always necessary information
    • Example: "The dogs that live down the street are always barking"
    • "Which" phrases are always unnecessary information
    • Example: "My neighbor's dogs, which are always barking, love to play fetch"
    • Exception: Prepositional phrases like "on which," "in which," or "of which" don't use commas before them

"ing" and "ed" Phrases

  • Participle phrases starting with "ing" or "ed" may or may not need commas
    • On the ACT, "ing" and "ed" phrases most commonly appear with commas as unnecessary information
    • Example: "Excited for the car ride, Jane's bulldog started to jump up and down"
    • Example: "Marcus applied for the internship, hoping that he would get the position"
    • If the phrase helps specify which noun, it's necessary (no commas)
    • Example: "The politician waving to the crowd is predicted to win the election"

Prepositional Phrases

  • Prepositional phrases consist of a preposition and its object
    • Common prepositions: in, of, to, for, with, on, at, from, by, about, as, into, like, through, after, over, between, during, before, among, around
    • Prepositional phrases at the FRONT of a sentence are always followed by a comma
    • Example: "On my way to work, I listened to my new favorite podcast"
    • Prepositional phrases in the MIDDLE or END almost never have commas (99% of the time)
    • Example: "The clothing on the bed is for vacation"
    • They contain essential information specifying which noun you're talking about

3. Transitional Words Like "However"

  • Transitional words (also called conjunctive adverbs) require specific punctuation
    • Common transitional words: however, though, therefore, instead, likewise, nevertheless, regardless, moreover, subsequently, furthermore, in addition, as a result, of course, otherwise, for example
    • These are NOT FANBOYS—they require different punctuation

Three Ways to Punctuate Transitional Words

  • Position 1: At the front of the sentence followed by a comma
    • Example: "However, the truth would not be revealed until next week"
    • Example: "As a result, the student was sent to the principal's office"
    • This treats the transitional word as unnecessary information you can cross out
  • Position 2: Separated by commas in the middle of a sentence
    • Example: "The truth, however, would not be revealed until next week"
    • Example: "The student, as a result, was sent to the principal's office"
    • Again, treat as unnecessary information between two commas
  • Position 3: Separated by a semicolon and comma when between two independent clauses
    • Example: "I expected to pay over $100 for my new hiking boots; however, I found a sale and got them for half price"
    • Structure: Independent clause + semicolon + transitional word + comma + Independent clause
    • CRITICAL: You need BOTH the semicolon (before) AND the comma (after) the transitional word

4. Spotting Unnecessary Information Comma Questions

  • Unnecessary information comma questions have two defining characteristics
    • The words in all 4 answer choices are exactly the same
    • The only difference is where commas are located
    • When you see this pattern, immediately use the "crossing-out" trick

How to Approach These Questions

  • Read the entire sentence carefully
    • Pay attention to any commas NOT in the underlined portion
    • These fixed commas are often important clues for finding the correct answer
    • Look out for sentence structure rules from Chapter 1 that may also apply
  • Use the crossing-out trick systematically
    • Test each answer choice by crossing out what the comma(s) would separate
    • The correct answer leaves a complete, grammatical sentence after crossing out

The Pauses and Commas Backup Trick

  • Read the sentence out loud (or "out loud" in your head on test day)
    • If you need to take a short pause for a breath, you likely need a comma
    • This is a backup method—always verify with the crossing-out trick first
    • Natural pauses often correspond to where unnecessary information appears

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The ACT tests exactly 4 comma types: (1) comma + FANBOYS joining independent clauses, (2) dependent clause before independent clause, (3) unnecessary information, and (4) listing items or adjectives
  • ✓Use the "crossing-out" trick for unnecessary information commas—if you can remove the information and still have a complete sentence, it's unnecessary and needs commas to separate it
  • ✓"That" phrases never get commas while "which" phrases always get commas—for names, use commas only when the identifier is specific to one person (best friend, CEO) but not for general identifiers (friend, teacher)
  • ✓Transitional words like "however" require specific punctuation: at the front with a comma after, in the middle between two commas, or between independent clauses with a semicolon before and comma after

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.3 - Advanced Punctuation
lessons.content:
Punctuation questions account for about 13% of the ACT English Test—roughly 10 questions per test! To master these questions, you need to understand the specific rules for semicolons, colons, dashes, apostrophes, and quotation marks.

1. Semicolons

  • The most important rule: A semicolon can replace a period
    • Both sides of the semicolon must be independent clauses (complete sentences)
    • If you can replace the semicolon with a period and both halves make sense as separate sentences, the semicolon is correct
    • Example: "My boss called me; he asked that I pick up coffee for him."
  • Common semicolon errors to avoid
    • ❌ Incorrect: "My boss called me; asking that I pick up coffee for him." (second half is not an independent clause)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "After my boss called me; he asked that I pick up coffee for him." (first half is not an independent clause)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "My boss called me, he asked that I pick up coffee for him." (this is a comma splice—cannot connect two independent clauses with just a comma)
  • The test: Replace the semicolon with a period
    • If both halves stand alone as complete sentences, the semicolon is correct
    • If either half cannot stand alone, the semicolon is wrong

2. Colons

  • A colon introduces a list, an example, an explanation, a clarification, or a definition
    • List of multiple items: "I went to the grocery store to pick up some items for dinner: chicken, cheese, and onions."
    • List of one item: "I went to the market to get lunch: a turkey sandwich."
    • Example or explanation: "He got what he deserved: a one-week suspension without pay."
    • Clarification: "Chocolate milk is a great recovery drink after a hard workout: it has the carbohydrates and proteins that muscles need to recover."

Three Critical Colon Rules

  • Rule 1: The part before the colon must be an independent clause
    • The part before the colon must be a complete sentence by itself
    • ❌ Incorrect: "The slide showing the most popular car colors in 2018: white, gray, and black."
    • ✓ Correct: "The slide shows the most popular car colors in 2018: white, gray, and black."
    • ❌ Incorrect: "The hairstylist excelled in: cuts, coloring, and highlights."
    • ✓ Correct: "The hairstylist excelled in cuts, coloring, and highlights." (no colon needed)
  • Rule 2: Everything after the colon must be only the list, example, explanation, clarification, or definition
    • The sentence cannot continue to other topics after the colon
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Will brought his lunch to the beach: a roast beef sandwich, and he brought his friend Joey a turkey club."
    • ✓ Correct: "Will brought his lunch to the beach: a roast beef sandwich. He brought his friend Joey a turkey club."
  • Rule 3: NEVER use colons with "including," "such as," or "for example"
    • If you see a colon before OR after these phrases, it is always incorrect
    • ❌ Incorrect: "I went to the grocery store to pick up some items for dinner, including: chicken, cheese, and onions."
    • ❌ Incorrect: "I went to the grocery store to pick up some items for dinner: including chicken, cheese, and onions."
    • ✓ Correct: "I went to the grocery store to pick up some items for dinner, including chicken, cheese, and onions." (use a comma instead)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "The study relied on techniques such as: direct observation and surveying."
    • ✓ Correct: "The study relied on techniques such as direct observation and surveying." (no comma or colon needed)

Advanced: Colons Joining Two Independent Clauses

  • A colon can join two independent clauses if the second clause acts as a definition, example, explanation, or clarification of the first
    • Example: "Buddy got what he worked for: he really deserved that promotion."
    • Example: "My father gave me one rule to live by: honesty is always the best policy."
    • This is an advanced grammar rule that rarely appears on the ACT

3. Dashes

  • Dashes can function like unnecessary information commas, parentheses, or colons
    • Most commonly, a pair of dashes sets apart unnecessary information in the middle of a sentence
    • Think of dashes as a stronger, more dramatic version of commas or parentheses

Pair of Dashes for Unnecessary Information

  • Two dashes function exactly like unnecessary information commas
    • Example: "Residents of Washington D.C. - the capital of the United States - are still trying to get representation in Congress."
    • Example: "Glazed donuts - even if they are unhealthy - are my favorite."
  • CRITICAL: You cannot mix punctuation!
    • Must be a pair of commas, a pair of dashes, OR a pair of parentheses
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Deep-dish pizza - a famous meal in Chicago, does not exist in Italy." (mixing dash and comma)
    • ✓ Correct: "Deep-dish pizza, a famous meal in Chicago, does not exist in Italy." (pair of commas)
    • ✓ Correct: "Deep-dish pizza - a famous meal in Chicago - does not exist in Italy." (pair of dashes)
    • ✓ Correct: "Deep-dish pizza (a famous meal in Chicago) does not exist in Italy." (pair of parentheses)

Single Dash Acting Like a Colon

  • A single dash can introduce a list, example, explanation, definition, or clarification
    • When acting as a colon, the dash must follow the same 3 colon rules
    • Example: "You will need the following ingredients - milk, butter, flour, and eggs."
    • Example: "In order to establish his dominance, the male lion relied on one thing - his thunderous roar."
    • Example: "The study declared that the results were conclusive - mice will complete the maze faster if they are given soda instead of water."

Advanced: Single Dash Like Parentheses

  • A single dash in the middle of a sentence can separate information at the end just like parentheses
    • Example: "After three weeks, the patient was fed up with his doctor's plan (or lack of a plan)."
    • Example: "After three weeks, the patient was fed up with his doctor's plan - or lack of a plan."
    • This rule has been very rarely tested on the ACT English Test

4. Apostrophes

  • Apostrophes on the ACT have two functions: possession and contractions
    • Most apostrophe questions test whether you can identify the correct possessive form
    • Other questions test whether you can distinguish between possessive pronouns and contractions

Possession Rules

  • For singular nouns: Add apostrophe + "s"
    • Example: "Terrence's bike is much faster than my brother's roller blades."
    • For singular words ending in "s" (like "bus"): You can add apostrophe + "s" OR just an apostrophe (both are correct)
    • Example: "The bus's driver" OR "The bus' driver"
  • For plural nouns ending in "s": Add apostrophe after the "s"
    • Example: "The boys' jerseys were all covered in mud after the game."
  • For plural nouns NOT ending in "s": Add apostrophe + "s"
    • Example: "Our women's basketball team won the championship last year."

Possessive vs. Plural

  • The ACT tests whether you can distinguish between singular possessive, plural possessive, and non-possessive plural
    • Singular possessive: "I accidentally stepped on the dog's bone." (one dog possessing the bone)
    • Plural possessive: "The dogs' collars are in the basket by the door." (multiple dogs possessing collars)
    • Non-possessive plural: "I watched as the dogs played in the yard." (multiple dogs, but no possession)
  • The trick: Check if the next word is being possessed
    • If the noun owns or possesses something, use an apostrophe
    • If there's no possession, don't use an apostrophe

Possessive Pronouns vs. Contractions

  • Possessive pronouns (its, hers, yours, ours, theirs) end in "s" but NEVER use an apostrophe
    • ✓ Correct: its, hers, yours, ours, theirs
    • ❌ Incorrect: it's (contraction for "it is"), her's, your's, our's, their's
  • Contractions use an apostrophe to show where letters are removed
    • "it's" = "it is" (contraction)
    • "you're" = "you are" (contraction)
    • "they're" = "they are" (contraction)
    • "who's" = "who is" (contraction)
  • The plug-in test: Expand the contraction and see if it makes sense
    • Example: "The cat loves playing with (its/it's) new toy."
    • Test: "The cat loves playing with it is new toy." ❌ This doesn't work!
    • Answer: "The cat loves playing with its new toy." ✓ Correct (possessive pronoun)

5. Quotation Marks

  • Quotation marks are most commonly used for direct quotes
    • They can also be used to show a word is being used as a technical term, slang, or in an unusual way

Direct Quotes That Are Spoken

  • Direct quotes that are spoken are offset by a comma
    • Anytime the quote is being spoken (said, yelled, whispered, exclaimed, etc.), use a comma before or after the quotation
    • Example: "Abigail said, 'I will not pay until the painting is completed.'"
    • Example: "'The thunderstorm last night woke me up,' Paul whispered."

Direct Quotes That Are NOT Spoken

  • Direct quotes that are not spoken have NO commas
    • If the quote is just a phrase or part of the sentence (not being actively spoken), there is no punctuation before the quotation marks
    • ❌ Incorrect: "My grandfather described the shells as, 'beautiful souvenirs from a past life.'"
    • ✓ Correct: "My grandfather described the shells as 'beautiful souvenirs from a past life.'"
    • The quotation marks show these are the grandfather's words, but he's not actively speaking them in the scene

Technical Terms, Slang, or Unusual Usage

  • Quotation marks can show a word is being used as a technical term, in an unusual way, or as slang
    • Technical term: "Having defined the term 'contact variance,' Dr. Chen continued his lecture."
    • Slang or sarcasm: "Sven refers to himself as a 'professional' influencer."
    • Unusual usage: "This 'revolutionary' program has left thousands of children without a basic education."
    • Irony: "Allie could smell the 'fresh' fish from across the room."

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Semicolons can replace periods—both sides must be independent clauses (complete sentences). Colons introduce lists, examples, explanations, or definitions, but the part before the colon must always be an independent clause, and you can never use colons with "including," "such as," or "for example."
  • ✓Dashes can function like unnecessary information commas or parentheses when used in pairs, and like colons when used as a single dash. Never mix punctuation—use a pair of commas, a pair of dashes, or a pair of parentheses, but never combine them.
  • ✓Apostrophes show possession (add apostrophe + "s" for singular nouns, apostrophe after "s" for plural nouns ending in "s") or contractions. Possessive pronouns like "its," "yours," and "theirs" never take apostrophes, while contractions like "it's" (it is), "you're" (you are), and "they're" (they are) always do.
  • ✓Quotation marks are used for direct quotes (with a comma if spoken, no comma if not spoken) and to show technical terms, slang, or unusual usage. When the quote is actively being said, yelled, or whispered, use a comma to offset it from the speaker tag.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.4 - Verbs
lessons.content:
Verb questions make up about 11% of the ACT English Test—roughly 8 questions per test! These questions test you on two major topics: subject-verb agreement and verb tense.

1. Subject-Verb Agreement Basics

  • The subject is the person, place, or thing doing the action
    • Usually at the beginning of the sentence
    • Example: "Cats love to sit in empty boxes." (subject = "Cats")
  • The subject must agree with the verb in number
    • If the subject is singular, the verb must be singular
    • If the subject is plural, the verb must be plural
    • Example: "My dog barks at the mailman every day." (singular subject "dog" → singular verb "barks")

Three Ways the ACT Tricks You

  • Trick #1: Unnecessary information phrases between subject and verb
    • Unnecessary information phrases NEVER contain the subject
    • Cross out unnecessary information to find the subject
    • Example: "Tortoises, known to live to over 150 years old, are sold at the local pet shop."
    • Cross out "known to live to over 150 years old" → Subject is "Tortoises" (plural) → verb is "are" (plural)
  • Trick #2: Prepositional phrases between subject and verb (MOST COMMON)
    • Prepositional phrases NEVER contain the subject or verb
    • Cross out prepositional phrases (like "of students," "in the park," "on the table") to find the subject
    • Example: "The entire group of students is organizing a bake sale to raise money."
    • Cross out "of students" → Subject is "group" (singular) → verb is "is" (singular)
    • Example: "The pod of dolphins hunts as a team."
    • Cross out "of dolphins" → Subject is "pod" (singular) → verb is "hunts" (singular)
  • Trick #3: Group nouns that sound plural but are singular
    • Group nouns (class, committee, team, herd, jury, etc.) are SINGULAR even though the group consists of more than one person or thing
    • Example: "The sheep herd waits to be sheared." (herd = singular)
    • Example: "The jury agrees that the defendant deserves to be put in jail." (jury = singular)

Helpful Tricks

  • Read the subject and verb side-by-side
    • Once you find the subject and verb, read them next to each other and ignore the information in between
    • Example: "A large percentage of the voters, many of whom are under the age of 30, prefers the new housing proposal."
    • Cross out unnecessary phrases → "A percentage prefers the new housing proposal."
    • Now it's clear: "percentage" (singular) → "prefers" (singular)
  • Plug in "he/she/it" for singular subjects and "they" for plural subjects
    • Sometimes it's difficult to "hear" which verb matches the subject
    • For singular words, plug in "he," "she," or "it"
    • For plural words, plug in "they"
    • Example: "The exact time for the meeting with the softball coach and location for the showcase have not been finalized."
    • Cross out prepositional phrases → Subjects are "time" and "location" (plural)
    • Replace with "they" → "They (has/have) not been finalized."
    • Now it's obvious: "have" is correct

2. Verb Tense

  • For verb tense questions, trust your ear
    • As a native English speaker, you'll know what sounds right or wrong
    • Read for context by looking at the previous sentence(s) and finding other verbs
    • Match the tense in the rest of the paragraph
  • Do NOT pick a complicated tense when a simple tense works
    • Avoid unnecessary complicated forms (has run, had ran, had been running, would have run) when simple tenses work
    • Example: "Last year, Margot designed a new line of summer dresses." (simple past tense, not "was designing")
    • Example: "Before he votes tomorrow, Dale will research each candidate's positions on the major issues." (simple future tense)

Perfect Tense (has/have/had + verb)

  • Use perfect tense when there are multiple timelines in a sentence
    • Perfect tense = "has," "have," or "had" + verb
    • Example: "Many surfers enjoy paddling out, but few have ridden waves over ten feet tall."
    • Example: "While the group of entrepreneurs claimed to all be successful, only a few have started their own businesses."
    • Example: "The bison had been eating when the lions began their attack." (shows the bison were already eating before the attack started)
    • Example: "By the beginning of next year, the doctors will have finished their preliminary research on lung cancer."

Conditional Tense (would/could)

  • Conditional tense describes what would or could happen
    • The verb conjugation depends on how likely the outcome is (probable, improbable, impossible)
    • Probable: "If I make the free throw, we will win the game."
    • Improbable: "If I made the free throw, we would win the game."
    • Impossible (past): "If I had made the free throw, we would have won the game."
    • Trust your ear and go with what sounds right

Irregular Verbs

  • Irregular verbs don't follow normal patterns
    • Trust your ear and go with what sounds correct
    • Example: "Before the show began, the lights were dimmed." (not "begun")
    • Example: "The deliveryman had rung the doorbell before dropping off the package." (not "rang")
  • The "a" vs. "u" rule for irregular verbs
    • Many irregular verbs have an "a" version (swam, began, drank) and a "u" version (swum, begun, drunk)
    • With "has," "have," or "had" (perfect tense) → Use the "u" version
    • Example: "Before you arrived, I had swum some laps." (perfect tense → "swum")
    • With no "has," "have," or "had" (past tense) → Use the "a" version
    • Example: "I swam some laps this morning." (past tense → "swam")

3. Common Irregular Verbs

  • The most commonly tested irregular verbs on the ACT
    • begin → began (past tense) → has/have/had begun (perfect tense)
    • drink → drank (past tense) → has/have/had drunk (perfect tense)
    • sink → sank (past tense) → has/have/had sunk (perfect tense)
    • swim → swam (past tense) → has/have/had swum (perfect tense)
    • run → ran (past tense) → has/have/had run (perfect tense)
    • sing → sang (past tense) → has/have/had sung (perfect tense)
  • Remember the pattern
    • Past tense (no helping verb) = "a" version
    • Perfect tense (with has/have/had) = "u" version
    • This pattern applies to begin, drink, sink, swim, and sing
    • Note: "run" is irregular—both versions are "run" (I ran, I have run)

4. How to Spot Subject-Verb Agreement vs. Verb Tense Questions

  • Both question types show different forms of the same verb in answer choices
    • You need to know which type you're dealing with to answer correctly
    • The answer choices tell you what's being tested

Subject-Verb Agreement Questions

  • Look for singular and plural versions of verbs in the answer choices
    • Look for "is" vs. "are"
    • Look for "has" vs. "have"
    • Look for "was" vs. "were"
    • Look for any verb with singular (like "runs") vs. plural (like "run")
    • Anytime you see singular and plural versions, the question is testing subject-verb agreement
  • Example
    • "The addition of solar panels to the roof of a house in Nevada makes the house on average 20% more energy efficient."
    • Answer choices: make (NO CHANGE), makes, have made, were making
    • Subject = "addition" (singular) → verb must be "makes" (singular)
    • Even though there are different tenses, we only need subject-verb agreement to find the answer

Verb Tense Questions

  • Look for different tenses in the answer choices
    • For example: "requires" (present), "required" (past), "will require" (future)
  • Check that answer choices do NOT have singular and plural versions
    • If there are no options for singular vs. plural, subject-verb agreement is not being tested
    • The question is testing verb tense only
  • Example
    • "The girl scouts are hosting a bake sale tomorrow to raise money. To get ready, Adya needs to bake two trays of blondies and a box of donut holes."
    • Answer choices: would need (NO CHANGE), was needing, needed, needs
    • Previous sentence uses "are" (present tense), so this sentence should be present tense too
    • Answer: "needs" (present tense)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓For subject-verb agreement, find the subject by crossing out unnecessary information phrases and prepositional phrases (which never contain the subject). The subject must match the verb in number—singular subjects take singular verbs, plural subjects take plural verbs. Watch out for group nouns (team, committee, herd) which are always singular.
  • ✓Use the "plug-in" trick for subject-verb agreement: replace singular subjects with "he/she/it" and plural subjects with "they" to easily hear which verb sounds correct. Read the subject and verb side-by-side, ignoring everything in between.
  • ✓For verb tense questions, trust your ear and read for context by looking at other verbs in the paragraph. Use perfect tense (has/have/had + verb) for multiple timelines, conditional tense (would/could) for hypothetical situations, and remember the "a" vs. "u" rule for irregular verbs: use "a" versions (swam, began, drank) for past tense without helping verbs, and "u" versions (swum, begun, drunk) with has/have/had.
  • ✓Identify question type by looking at answer choices: if you see singular vs. plural versions ("is" vs. "are," "has" vs. "have," "runs" vs. "run"), it's testing subject-verb agreement. If you see different tenses without singular/plural options, it's testing verb tense. This tells you which strategy to use.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.5 - Pronouns
lessons.content:
Pronoun questions make up about 9% of the ACT English Test—roughly 7 questions per test! You'll need to know how to select the proper pronoun based on case ("he" vs. "him" or "who" vs. "whom"), make sure that a pronoun agrees with the word it's replacing, and spot ambiguous pronouns.

1. Pronoun Case: Subject vs. Object

  • Pronouns are words that stand in for a person, place, or thing
    • Pronouns have two cases: subject and object
    • The pronoun's role in the sentence (subject or object) dictates which type is correct

Subject Pronouns vs. Object Pronouns

  • Subject pronouns (I, we, you, he, she, it, they, who) are used when the pronoun is doing the action
    • Example: "They went to the street festival on Saturday afternoon."
  • Object pronouns (me, us, you, him, her, it, them, whom) are used when the pronoun is receiving the action
    • Example: "The man handed us a stack of flyers."
  • For simple pronoun case questions, trust your ear

Pronouns in a List

  • Pronouns in lists are tricky because we often say them incorrectly in conversation
    • Ignore the other items in the list and just read the pronoun by itself to tell which is correct
    • Example: "The policeman asked to speak to my friends and me."
    • Test: "The policeman asked to speak to me." ✓ (not "speak to I")
    • Example: "His girlfriend and he went to the hockey game."
    • Test: "He went to the hockey game." ✓ (not "him went")

Pronouns in Prepositional Phrases

  • Pronouns in prepositional phrases are ALWAYS in the object case
    • This rule can be difficult to hear by ear alone, so remember it
    • Example: "The bet between Joe and me was for just five dollars." (not "between Joe and I")
    • Example: "To whom was the award given?" (not "to who")
    • Example: "Jerry claims that a great rivalry exists among Tim, Scott, and him." (not "among...and he")

Who vs. Whom

  • The difference between "who" and "whom" is tested on almost every ACT
    • Technically, "who" is the subject and "whom" is the object
    • But here's the trick you need to memorize:
  • The he/him replacement trick
    • If you can replace the word with "he," "she," or "they" → use "who"
    • If you can replace the word with "him," "her," or "them" → use "whom"
    • You may need to rearrange the sentence, but this trick works for any who vs. whom question
  • Examples
    • "Who stole the apple off the teacher's desk?" → Test: "He stole the apple" ✓ → Use "who"
    • "To whom should I address this letter?" → Test: "I should address this letter to him" ✓ → Use "whom"
    • "Who do you want to win the Bachelor?" → Test: "You want him to win" ✓ → Actually "whom" is correct here!

Who vs. Whom in Descriptive Phrases

  • On difficult questions, who/whom can introduce a phrase describing a person
    • The normal "he/him" trick doesn't work if you look at the entire sentence
    • Instead, look only at the phrase itself
  • Example: "The child whom I invited to the party was very noisy."
    • Look only at the phrase: "whom I invited to the party"
    • Test: "I invited him to the party" ✓ → Use "whom"
  • Example: "The child who was running down the street was very noisy."
    • Look only at the phrase: "who was running down the street"
    • Test: "He was running down the street" ✓ → Use "who"
  • Quick trick: Look at the word right after "who" or "whom"
    • If the word right after is a verb → use "who"
    • If the word right after is a noun → use "whom"

Reflexive Pronouns (myself, yourself, himself...)

  • Reflexive pronouns use the "-self" ending and can only be used when the pronoun refers back to a person or thing elsewhere in the sentence
    • ✓ Correct: "I grabbed three donuts and put them in a box for myself." (refers back to "I")
    • ❌ Incorrect: "I asked my coworker to put three donuts in a box for myself." ("myself" doesn't work because the subject is "my coworker," not "I")
    • ✓ Correct: "I asked my coworker to put three donuts in a box for me."

2. Possessive Pronouns

  • Possessive pronouns show ownership
    • These pronouns must match with the word(s) they're replacing
    • They come in two forms: possessive nouns and possessive adjectives

Possessive Nouns vs. Possessive Adjectives

  • Possessive nouns stand alone: mine, ours, yours, his, hers, its, theirs
    • Example: "That book is mine." (stands alone, not followed by a noun)
  • Possessive adjectives come before a noun: my, our, your, his, her, its, their
    • Example: "That is my book." (comes before the noun "book")

Matching Possessive Pronouns to the Antecedent

  • Possessive pronouns must match the word they're replacing in number (singular vs. plural)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "The entire team went on stage to pick up their trophy."
    • The pronoun refers back to "team," which is singular (remember: group nouns are singular!)
    • ✓ Correct: "The entire team went on stage to pick up its trophy."
  • More examples
    • "Emmanuel and James came back home after forgetting their phones." (plural subjects → "their")
    • "Thousands of tourists travel to Egypt each year to see its ancient pyramids." (Egypt is singular → "its")

3. Pronoun Agreement

  • Pronouns must agree with the antecedent, which is the noun the pronoun is replacing
    • Whenever you see a pronoun on the ACT, find exactly who or what it's referring to
    • The antecedent can be in the same sentence or in a preceding sentence
    • The antecedent can appear anywhere (unnecessary information, prepositional phrases, etc.)

Matching in Plurality

  • A singular antecedent must have a singular pronoun; a plural antecedent must have a plural pronoun
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Each attendee at the party raised their drink for a toast."
    • "Each attendee" is singular → pronoun must be singular
    • ✓ Correct: "Each attendee at the party raised his or her drink for a toast."
    • ✓ Also correct: "The guests at the party raised their drinks for a toast." (plural → plural)

Matching in Gender

  • A male antecedent must have a male pronoun; a female antecedent must have a female pronoun
    • Example: "Jane and Sarah, after a long conversation with another group of hikers on the trail, said they were too tired to go any farther today."
    • "Jane and Sarah" (female, plural) → "they" (plural, works for any gender)

Common Tricky Cases

  • Watch out for singular words that seem plural
    • "Each member of the women's track team improved her time." ("each member" is singular → "her")
    • "A person who is committed to his or her dreams can achieve them." ("a person" is singular → "his or her")
  • Consistency with pronoun style
    • "If you plan to give a presentation on the importance of accurate data, you should check your facts first."
    • Keep the same pronoun style throughout: "you...you...your" (not "you...one...one's")

4. Ambiguous Pronouns

  • For a pronoun to be correct, we must know exactly who or what it's referring to
    • If we don't know exactly who or what a pronoun is referring to, the pronoun is ambiguous and is always incorrect

Examples of Ambiguous Pronouns

  • Ambiguous "he"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Stephen smiled at his father as he threw the ball."
    • We don't know if "he" refers to Stephen or his father, so "he" is ambiguous
    • ✓ Correct: "Stephen smiled at his father as his father threw the ball."
    • Even though it seems redundant, replacing "he" with "his father" fixes the error
  • Ambiguous "some"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Even though the order had not yet shown up, the librarian insisted that she had ordered some."
    • We have no idea what "some" refers to
    • ✓ Correct: "Even though the order had not yet shown up, the librarian insisted that she had ordered four copies of the new book."

Spotting Ambiguous Pronouns Questions

  • Anytime you see a pronoun in the answer choices, check if it's ambiguous
    • Pronouns to watch for: he, him, his, she, her, hers, they, them, their, it, its, this, that, these, those, some, none
  • Look for answer choices that replace the pronoun with a specific noun
    • The correct answer often specifies exactly what or who is being referred to
    • Example: Instead of "he is the most famous," the answer might be "Biggie is the most famous"
    • Example: Instead of "asked for one," the answer might be "asked for a slider"

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Use subject pronouns (I, we, he, she, they, who) when the pronoun does the action, and object pronouns (me, us, him, her, them, whom) when it receives the action. For pronouns in lists, ignore the other items and read the pronoun alone. Pronouns in prepositional phrases are always object case. For "who" vs. "whom," replace with "he/him"—if "he" works, use "who"; if "him" works, use "whom."
  • ✓Possessive pronouns must match the word they're replacing in number. Remember that group nouns (team, committee, class) are singular and take singular possessive pronouns like "its," not "their."
  • ✓Pronouns must agree with their antecedent (the noun they're replacing) in both plurality and gender. A singular antecedent needs a singular pronoun; a plural antecedent needs a plural pronoun. Watch out for singular words like "each," "every," and "a person" that require singular pronouns.
  • ✓Ambiguous pronouns are always incorrect. If you can't tell exactly who or what a pronoun refers to, it's ambiguous. The correct answer will replace the ambiguous pronoun with a specific noun. Watch for pronouns like he, she, they, it, this, that, some, and one in answer choices—they're often ambiguous and need to be replaced with specific nouns.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.6 - Misplaced Modifiers
lessons.content:
Misplaced modifier questions make up about 5-7% of the ACT English Test—roughly 4-5 questions per test! These questions test whether descriptive words, phrases, or clauses are placed next to the nouns they're supposed to modify.

1. What is a Misplaced Modifier?

  • A misplaced modifier is a word, phrase, or clause that is improperly separated from the noun it modifies
    • This leads to a sentence with an incorrect or unintended meaning
    • Misplaced modifiers are hard to spot because we usually know what the sentence is really supposed to be saying

Example of a Misplaced Modifier

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Consistently erupting, Jack loves taking pictures of the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park."
    • What's wrong? The modifier "consistently erupting" is supposed to modify the Old Faithful geyser, but instead it's modifying Jack!
    • This sentence suggests Jack is consistently erupting (which doesn't make sense)
  • When a sentence begins with a modifying phrase, the phrase must modify the very first noun that follows the comma

How to Fix Misplaced Modifiers

  • Option 1: Put the modifier right next to what it's describing
    • ✓ Correct: "Consistently erupting, the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park is one of Jack's favorite things to take pictures of."
    • Now "consistently erupting" is right next to "the Old Faithful geyser"
  • Option 2: Change the modifier from a phrase to a dependent clause
    • ✓ Correct: "Since it is consistently erupting, Jack loves taking pictures of the Old Faithful geyser at Yellowstone National Park."
    • Adding "it is" changes the modifier to a dependent clause, making it clear the geyser is erupting

The "Next-Door Neighbor" Rule

  • For a modifier to be properly placed, it must be right "next-door" to the noun it's describing
    • Modifiers can be at the beginning, middle, or end of a sentence
  • If the modifier is at the beginning of the sentence, the first noun after it must be the word being modified
    • Example: "Running from the police, Eric hopped the fence and hid underneath a car."
    • "Running from the police" modifies "Eric" (the first noun after the comma)
  • If the modifier is in the middle or end of the sentence, it must be modifying the noun directly before it
    • Example: "Dr. Anderson, a world-renowned surgeon, fixed my broken leg."
    • "A world-renowned surgeon" modifies "Dr. Anderson" (the noun directly before it)

2. Front of the Sentence Modifiers with a Comma

  • On the ACT, most misplaced modifier questions have a modifier at the front of the sentence separated by a comma
    • For this type of question, consider who or what the modifier is describing
    • Then make sure that person, place, or thing is the first noun in the rest of the sentence

Example: Front Modifier Error

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Not popular since the early 1980s, the documentary about mullets explored the origins of the wildly popular hairstyle."
    • The modifier is "not popular since the early 1980s"
    • What is "not popular since the early 1980s"? Mullets, not documentaries!
    • But the first noun after the comma is "documentary," which is wrong
  • ✓ Correct: "Not popular since the early 1980s, mullets were the topic of a recently released documentary."
    • Now "mullets" (the thing that's not popular since the 1980s) is the first noun after the comma
    • The modifier is right "next-door" to what it describes

Strategy for Front Modifiers

  • Step 1: Identify the modifying phrase at the beginning (before the comma)
    • Look for descriptive phrases before the first comma
  • Step 2: Ask yourself: Who or what is being described by this modifier?
    • Think about what noun makes logical sense with the description
  • Step 3: Find the first noun after the comma
    • This is what the modifier is currently describing
  • Step 4: Make sure the first noun matches who or what should be described
    • If it doesn't match, the modifier is misplaced
    • Choose the answer that puts the correct noun first

3. Middle or End of the Sentence Modifiers with Commas

  • A modifier in the middle or at the end of the sentence must be directly after whoever or whatever it is modifying
    • These modifiers are often set off by commas or use "which" or "that"

Example: Middle Modifier Error

  • ❌ Incorrect: "The research team, which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year, tracked the movements of the blue storks."
    • The modifier is "which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year"
    • This is placed right after "research team," so it's describing the research team
    • But the blue storks (not the research team) arrived at their nesting grounds early!

How to Fix Middle/End Modifiers

  • Option 1: Move the modifier to be right after what it describes
    • ✓ Correct: "The research team tracked the movements of the blue storks, which arrived at their nesting grounds early this year."
    • Now the modifier is right after "blue storks"
  • Option 2: Change the modifier to describe what's actually before it
    • ✓ Correct: "The research team, which tracked the movement of the blue storks, noted that the birds arrived at their nesting grounds early."
    • Now the modifier correctly describes the research team

Strategy for Middle/End Modifiers

  • Step 1: Identify the modifying phrase (often with "which," "that," or set off by commas)
    • Look for descriptive phrases in the middle or end of the sentence
  • Step 2: Ask: What noun is the modifier describing?
    • Think logically about what makes sense
  • Step 3: Check what noun comes right before the modifier
    • This is what the modifier is currently describing
  • Step 4: Make sure the noun before the modifier is what should be described
    • If not, choose the answer that moves the modifier or changes the sentence structure

4. Modifiers without Commas

  • In some questions, the modifier will not be separated by any commas
    • These are harder to spot, but the "next-door neighbor" rule still applies
    • Keep an eye out for phrases starting with "that" or words ending in "-ing" and "-ed"

Common Patterns without Commas

  • Phrases starting with "that"
    • Example: "The book that I borrowed from the library is overdue."
    • "That I borrowed from the library" modifies "book" (right before it)
  • Words ending in "-ing" (present participles)
    • Example: "The dog chasing the cat ran into the street."
    • "Chasing the cat" modifies "dog" (right before it)
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Chasing the cat, the street was where the dog ran."
    • This suggests the street is chasing the cat!
  • Words ending in "-ed" (past participles)
    • Example: "The cake baked by my grandmother was delicious."
    • "Baked by my grandmother" modifies "cake" (right before it)

Strategy for Modifiers without Commas

  • Look for descriptive phrases that aren't set off by commas
    • Watch for "that," "-ing," and "-ed" words
  • Apply the same "next-door neighbor" rule
    • The modifier should be right next to what it's describing
    • If it's at the beginning, check the first noun after it
    • If it's in the middle or end, check the noun right before it
  • Ask yourself: Does the modifier logically describe the noun next to it?
    • If not, it's misplaced

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓A misplaced modifier is a word, phrase, or clause that is improperly separated from the noun it modifies, leading to a sentence with an incorrect or unintended meaning. Use the "next-door neighbor" rule: modifiers must be right next to the nouns they describe.
  • ✓For front-of-sentence modifiers separated by a comma, the first noun after the comma must be what the modifier describes. Ask yourself: "Who or what is being described by this modifier?" and make sure that noun comes first after the comma.
  • ✓For middle or end-of-sentence modifiers with commas (often using "which" or "that"), the modifier must come directly after the noun it describes. Check what noun comes right before the modifier—that's what it's currently modifying—and make sure it's the correct noun.
  • ✓Modifiers without commas follow the same "next-door neighbor" rule. Watch for phrases starting with "that" or words ending in "-ing" and "-ed." These descriptive phrases must be right next to the nouns they modify, whether at the beginning, middle, or end of the sentence.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.7 - Parallel Structure
lessons.content:
Parallel structure questions make up about 7-9% of the ACT English Test—roughly 5-7 questions per test! These questions test whether items in a list or comparison are written with the same grammatical form.

1. What is Parallel Structure?

  • Parallel structure is the repetition of a chosen grammatical form within a sentence as items are listed or compared
    • The items in a list can be words, phrases, or clauses
    • Whenever we see items in a list or a comparison between items, we must make sure they have parallel structure
  • Items in any list must be written with the same grammatical form
    • Items must be all nouns, all verbs, all adjectives, etc.
    • When lists are written with proper parallel structure, the sentence flows more smoothly and sounds better
    • Many students can "hear" which answer choice is correct without even realizing they're being tested on parallel structure

Examples of Parallel Structure Errors

  • ❌ Incorrect: "To protect her fragile hands, Julia will not rake the leaves, wash the dishes, and has decided she will not take out the trash."
    • List items: "rake the leaves" (verb phrase), "wash the dishes" (verb phrase), "has decided she will not take out the trash" (clause)
    • Not parallel! The third item is much longer and has a different structure
  • ✓ Correct: "To protect her fragile hands, Julia will not rake the leaves, wash the dishes, or take out the trash."
    • All three items are now verb phrases: "rake," "wash," "take out"
    • Parallel!

2. Parallel Structure with Lists

  • No matter how simple or complex the items in the list are, they must be parallel
    • Lists can contain nouns, verb phrases, adjectives, or entire clauses
    • All items must match in grammatical form

Lists of Nouns or Noun Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "Elon Musk is known for self-driving cars and pioneering the SpaceX program."
    • "Self-driving cars" (noun phrase) vs. "pioneering the SpaceX program" (verb phrase)
    • Not parallel!
  • ✓ Correct: "Elon Musk is known for self-driving cars and the SpaceX program."
    • Both are noun phrases: "self-driving cars" and "the SpaceX program"
  • ✓ Also correct: "Elon Musk is known for manufacturing self-driving cars and pioneering the SpaceX program."
    • Both are verb phrases: "manufacturing" and "pioneering"

Lists of Verb Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "After calling in sick to school, Charlie hoped to get excused from class, receiving an extension on his homework assignment, and spend the afternoon watching movies at home."
    • "To get excused" (infinitive), "receiving" (gerund), "spend" (base verb)
    • Not parallel!
  • ✓ Correct: "After calling in sick to school, Charlie hoped to get excused from class, receive an extension on his homework assignment, and spend the afternoon watching movies at home."
    • All three use the base verb form after "hoped to": "get," "receive," "spend"
    • Parallel!

Lists of 3+ vs. Lists of 2

  • Lists of 3 or more items are easier to spot
    • You will be able to more obviously "hear" which answer choice is correct or incorrect
    • Example: "She made her bed, cleaned the shelves, and swept the floor" (all past tense verbs)
  • Lists of 2 are more difficult to spot and can trick you
    • They can often sound good even if they're not parallel
    • Be extra aware of parallel structure anytime you see a list of 2 on the ACT
    • ❌ Incorrect: "It's harder to lift the couch by myself than lifting it with some friends."
    • ✓ Correct: "It's harder to lift the couch by myself than to lift it with some friends." (both use "to lift")

3. Special Cases: Correlative Conjunctions

  • In addition to lists, there are certain special cases for parallel structure
    • These are officially called correlative conjunctions
    • They must have the same grammatical structure for both parts of the conjunction

The Four Main Correlative Conjunctions

  • Neither ___ nor ___
    • Example: "The news report is neither accurate nor fair."
    • Both blanks must have the same form (both adjectives here)
  • Either ___ or ___
    • Example: "You can either call me or text me."
    • Both blanks must match (both verb phrases here)
  • Not only ___ but also ___
    • This is the most commonly tested correlative conjunction on the ACT
    • Example: "My mother not only took away my keys but also locked them in the safe."
    • Both blanks must match (both verb phrases here)
  • Both ___ and ___
    • Example: "Both a scholar and an athlete, Sylvia got a scholarship to row crew in college."
    • Both blanks must match (both noun phrases here)

How to Check Parallel Structure with Correlative Conjunctions

  • Identify what comes immediately after the first part of the conjunction
    • What type of word or phrase follows "not only," "either," "neither," or "both"?
  • Check what comes immediately after the second part
    • What type of word or phrase follows "but also," "or," "nor," or "and"?
  • Make sure both parts match in grammatical form
    • If the first part has a verb phrase, the second must have a verb phrase
    • If the first part has a noun, the second must have a noun

4. Common Parallel Structure Patterns

  • Watch for these common patterns on the ACT
    • Lists connected by "and" or "or"
    • Comparisons using "than"
    • Correlative conjunctions (neither/nor, either/or, not only/but also, both/and)

Strategy for Parallel Structure Questions

  • Step 1: Identify that there's a list or comparison
    • Look for words like "and," "or," "than," or correlative conjunctions
  • Step 2: Find all the items in the list or comparison
    • How many items are there? What are they?
  • Step 3: Check the grammatical form of each item
    • Is the first item a noun? Verb? Adjective? Phrase? Clause?
    • Are all the other items the same type?
  • Step 4: Choose the answer that makes all items match
    • All items must have the same grammatical structure
    • Trust your ear—parallel structure usually "sounds right"

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Parallel structure is the repetition of a chosen grammatical form within a sentence as items are listed or compared. Items in a list must all be the same type—all nouns, all verbs, all adjectives, etc. When lists have proper parallel structure, sentences flow smoothly and sound better.
  • ✓Lists of 3 or more items are easier to spot because you can clearly hear when one item doesn't match the others. Lists of 2 are trickier and can sound correct even when they're not parallel, so pay extra attention to comparisons using "than" and two-item lists connected by "and" or "or."
  • ✓Correlative conjunctions (neither/nor, either/or, not only/but also, both/and) require parallel structure on both sides. Whatever grammatical form comes after the first part must match the grammatical form that comes after the second part. "Not only/but also" is the most commonly tested on the ACT.
  • ✓To check parallel structure, identify all items in the list or comparison, determine the grammatical form of each item, and make sure they all match. Trust your ear—parallel structure usually sounds right, and non-parallel structure often sounds awkward or choppy.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.8 - Miscellaneous Topics
lessons.content:
Miscellaneous grammar questions make up about 8-10% of the ACT English Test—roughly 6-8 questions per test! This chapter covers commonly confused words, active vs. passive voice, and other important grammar rules that don't fit into other categories.

1. Commonly Confused Words

  • The ACT tests many commonly confused words
    • The most common is "affect" vs. "effect"
    • If you're unsure, go with your gut—you'll usually be correct

Affect vs. Effect

  • Affect = verb meaning to act on or produce a change in
    • Example: "Sunshine and palm trees affect my mood positively."
  • Effect = noun meaning the result of a change
    • Example: "Sunshine and palm trees have a positive effect on my mood."

Other Commonly Confused Words

  • Accept (receive) vs. Except (exclude)
  • Advice (noun - recommendation) vs. Advise (verb - to recommend)
  • Lie (to lie down) vs. Lay (to place)
  • Lose (to misplace) vs. Loose (not tight)
  • Passed (moved beyond) vs. Past (gone by in time)
  • Principal (head of school) vs. Principle (a rule)
  • Their (possessive) vs. There (location) vs. They're (they are)
  • To (toward) vs. Too (also) vs. Two (2)

2. Than vs. Then

  • Than is ONLY used for comparisons
    • Example: "I think that chocolate with almonds is much better than ice cream."
  • Then has multiple meanings
    • Used when dealing with time: "First we eat, then we clean up."
    • Means "in addition to": "I need to call my mother, and then we can leave."
    • Used with if/then statements: "If it rains, then we'll stay inside."
  • Quick rule: For a comparison, use "than." Otherwise, use "then."

3. Have vs. Of

  • Many people mistakenly use "could of" or "would of"
    • This is ALWAYS incorrect!
    • The correct forms are "could have" or "would have"
  • The words "could," "should," "would," and "might" should always be followed by "have," not "of"
    • The reason for this mistake: The contraction "could've" (short for "could have") is pronounced like "could of"
    • ❌ Incorrect: "If we left the show earlier, we could of avoided the traffic."
    • ✓ Correct: "If we left the show earlier, we could have avoided the traffic."

4. Countable vs. Non-countable Adjectives

  • A countable noun is something you can count
    • Examples: bottles of milk, hours, trophies, calories
  • A non-countable noun is something that cannot be expressed in plural form
    • Examples: time, air, milk, significance

Which Adjectives to Use

  • For COUNTABLE nouns, use: number, many, fewer, few
    • Example: "The number of ingredients" (you can count ingredients)
    • Example: "How many trophies" (you can count trophies)
    • Example: "Fewer calories" (you can count calories)
    • Example: "A few minutes" (you can count minutes)
  • For NON-COUNTABLE nouns, use: amount, much, less, little
    • Example: "The amount of time" (you can't count time itself)
    • Example: "How much significance" (you can't count significance)
    • Example: "Less whole milk" (you can't count milk itself, only containers)
    • Example: "A little time" (you can't count time itself)

5. Active Voice vs. Passive Voice

  • Active voice means the subject performs the verb's action
    • Example: "I picked up the pencil." (I performed the action)
    • Example: "The police chief announced the list of suspects." (The police chief performed the action)
  • Passive voice means the subject is acted upon by the verb
    • Example: "The pencil was picked up by me." (The pencil didn't do the action)
    • Example: "The list of suspects was announced by the police chief." (The list didn't do the action)
  • On the ACT, NEVER select an answer choice in passive voice
    • Active voice is always better than passive voice
    • Active voice is clearer, more direct, and stronger

6. Prepositional Idioms

  • Idioms are expressions stated in a certain way because it's widely accepted practice
    • Certain words must be paired with certain prepositions to be correct
    • These questions don't come up often on the ACT
  • When prepositional idioms appear, rely on what sounds best
    • ❌ Incorrect: "Bobby was afraid by the dark."
    • ✓ Correct: "Bobby was afraid of the dark."
  • Common prepositional idioms to know
    • Afraid of (not afraid by)
    • Anxious about (not anxious of)
    • Different from (not different than)
    • Responsible for (not responsible of)

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓"Affect" is a verb (to produce a change), while "effect" is a noun (the result of a change). "Than" is only for comparisons, while "then" is for time sequences or if/then statements. Always use "could have" not "could of"—the same applies to should, would, and might.
  • ✓For countable nouns (things you can count), use number, many, fewer, and few. For non-countable nouns (things you can't count in plural form), use amount, much, less, and little. For example: "fewer calories" but "less milk."
  • ✓Active voice (where the subject performs the action) is always better than passive voice (where the subject is acted upon) on the ACT. Choose "I picked up the pencil" over "The pencil was picked up by me."
  • ✓Prepositional idioms pair specific words with specific prepositions (like "afraid of" not "afraid by"). These questions are rare—when they appear, trust what sounds right. Don't try to memorize every idiom; focus on mastering other topics first.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 1.9 - Grammar Review
lessons.content:
This comprehensive grammar review synthesizes all the major concepts tested on the ACT English Test. Now that you've studied individual topics, it's essential to develop integrated strategies, error recognition patterns, and efficient test-taking approaches. The ACT doesn't announce which grammar rule each question tests—you must quickly identify error types and apply the appropriate fix. This lesson provides a systematic framework for approaching any grammar question with confidence and speed.

1. The Complete Grammar Error Checklist

When you encounter an underlined portion, systematically check for the most common error types. This mental checklist helps you identify problems quickly without wasting time.

The "Big 7" Grammar Categories

These seven categories account for approximately 70-80% of all grammar questions on the ACT:

1. Punctuation (15-18 questions) Commas, semicolons, colons, dashes, apostrophes 2. Sentence Structure (15-18 questions) Fragments, run-ons, comma splices, subordination 3. Verbs (8-10 questions) Agreement, tense, form, voice 4. Pronouns (5-7 questions)

Agreement, case, clarity, reference 5. Modifiers (4-6 questions) Misplaced, dangling, squinting modifiers 6. Parallel Structure (3-5 questions) Lists, conjunctions, comparisons 7. Word Choice & Idioms (3-5 questions) Commonly confused words, prepositional idioms

Quick Diagnostic Questions

Ask yourself these questions in order when you see an underlined portion:

→ Is there punctuation? Check comma rules, semicolon/colon usage → Is there a verb? Check subject-verb agreement, tense, form → Is there a pronoun? Check agreement, case, clear antecedent → Does the sentence begin with a phrase? Check for dangling modifiers

→ Is there a list or conjunction? Check parallel structure → Can the sentence stand alone? Check for fragments/run-ons

Common Error Combinations

The ACT often tests multiple concepts in one question. Watch for these combinations:

Comma + Verb Agreement: Prepositional phrase between subject and verb, with comma placement Modifier + Pronoun: Dangling modifier where the pronoun reference is ambiguous Parallel + Verb Tense: List items with inconsistent verb forms

2. Systematic Error Recognition Strategies

Develop a consistent approach to every grammar question. This systematic method prevents you from missing errors and helps you work efficiently under time pressure.

Step 1: Read the Sentence Completely

Always read from the beginning of the sentence (or previous sentence if needed) through the end. Context matters—you can't identify tense errors, pronoun agreement, or modifier placement without understanding the full sentence.
