Why this matters: Many errors depend on elements outside the underlined portion. Subject-verb agreement requires finding the subject (often not underlined). Verb tense requires checking surrounding verbs. Pronoun clarity requires seeing the antecedent.

Step 2: Trust Your Ear, But Verify with Rules

If something sounds wrong, it probably is. However, some errors sound correct (like "everyone...their"), so verify with the rules you've learned.

Ear + Rules = Accuracy → If it sounds wrong: Identify which rule is violated → If it sounds right: Still check the Big 7 categories systematically

Step 3: Eliminate Obviously Wrong Answers

Use process of elimination to narrow choices before identifying the specific error.

Common eliminators:

• Creates a fragment or run-on • Uses wrong verb tense for the context • Creates pronoun agreement error • Breaks parallel structure in a list • Makes the sentence significantly more wordy without adding clarity

Step 4: Look for Visual Cues

Certain patterns in the answer choices tell you what the question is testing.

Different punctuation marks? → Punctuation question Different verb forms? → Verb agreement or tense Different pronouns? → Pronoun agreement or case Sentence restructured? → Modifier placement or sentence structure Different word order in list? → Parallel structure

3. Time Management and Pacing

The ACT English section gives you 45 minutes for 75 questions across 5 passages. That's 36 seconds per question or 9 minutes per passage. Effective time management is crucial for finishing strong.

The 9-Minute Per Passage Strategy

Aim to complete each passage in approximately 9 minutes, which includes reading and answering all 15 questions.

Minute 0-2: Read the passage naturally, answering inline grammar questions as you encounter them Minute 2-7: Work through remaining grammar and style questions systematically Minute 7-9: Handle rhetorical skills questions (organization, purpose, style)

Quick vs. Slow Questions

Not all questions take equal time. Recognize which should be fast and which require more thought.

Quick questions (15-20 seconds):

• Obvious verb agreement errors • Clear punctuation rules (commas with introductory phrases) • Obvious fragments or run-ons • Word choice errors (their/there/they're)

Slower questions (45-60 seconds):

• Rhetorical skills (transitions, adding/deleting sentences) • Complex modifier questions requiring sentence restructuring • Pronoun clarity when multiple antecedents possible • Organization questions (sentence placement)

When to Skip and Return

If you're stuck after 45 seconds, mark your best guess, circle the question number, and move on. Return to it if you have time at the end.

Critical Strategy: Never leave questions blank. Even if you're unsure, eliminate obviously wrong answers and make an educated guess. There's no guessing penalty on the ACT.

Pacing Checkpoints

Check your progress at these intervals to ensure you're on track:

15 minutes: Should be finishing passage 2 (question 30) 30 minutes: Should be finishing passage 4 (question 60) 40 minutes: Should be on passage 5 with 5 minutes to finish

4. Test Day Strategies and Final Tips

Beyond knowing grammar rules, test day success requires strategic approaches to maximize your score. These final strategies help you navigate the test efficiently and avoid common pitfalls.

When "NO CHANGE" Is Correct

About 20-25% of questions have "NO CHANGE" as the correct answer. Don't avoid this choice if you can't find an error.

Choose NO CHANGE when:

• You've checked all grammar rules and found no violations • Other answer choices create new errors • Other choices are unnecessarily wordy • The original is clear, concise, and correct

Shorter Is Usually Better

When choosing between grammatically correct options, the ACT typically favors conciseness. If two answers are both correct, choose the shorter one.

Example:

✗ Wordy: due to the fact that ✓ Concise: because

However: Never sacrifice clarity or correctness for brevity. If the shorter version creates an error or changes meaning, choose the longer correct option.

Avoid Extreme or Absolute Language

On rhetorical questions about adding/deleting information or main ideas, be wary of answer choices with extreme words like "always," "never," "only," "completely."

Read Answer Choices Carefully

The ACT loves to include answer choices that look similar but differ in one key detail. Read every word of each choice.

Common trap: Three choices are identical except one uses "affects" and another uses "effects." Missing this difference means picking the wrong answer.

Grammar Doesn't Always "Sound" Wrong

Some grammatically incorrect constructions sound natural in casual speech. Trust the rules over your ear in these cases:

• "Everyone brought their book" sounds fine but is grammatically wrong (everyone = singular) • "Between you and I" sounds formal but is wrong (object of preposition = me) • "The team are winning" sounds right to some but is wrong (team = singular)

Final Mental Checklist

Before moving to the next question, quickly verify:

✓ Your answer creates no new errors ✓ The sentence is complete and logical ✓ All subjects have verbs and all verbs have subjects ✓ Pronouns have clear antecedents ✓ Modifiers are placed next to what they describe

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓The Big 7 categories: Systematically check punctuation, sentence structure, verbs, pronouns, modifiers, parallel structure, and word choice for every underlined portion; these account for 70-80% of all grammar questions
  • ✓Systematic approach: Always read the complete sentence for context, trust your ear but verify with rules, eliminate obviously wrong answers, and look for visual cues in answer choices to identify what's being tested
  • ✓Time management: Aim for 9 minutes per passage (36 seconds per question); recognize quick questions (15-20 seconds) vs. slow questions (45-60 seconds); check pacing at 15, 30, and 40 minute marks
  • ✓Test day strategies: "NO CHANGE" is correct 20-25% of the time; when both answers are grammatically correct, choose the shorter one; never leave blanks (no guessing penalty); read all answer choices carefully
  • ✓Final verification: Before moving on, confirm your answer creates no new errors, the sentence is complete and logical, all subjects have verbs, pronouns have clear antecedents, and modifiers are correctly placed

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - Redundancy & Wordiness
lessons.content:
Redundancy, wordiness, and irrelevance questions appear frequently on the ACT English Test. For these questions, the shortest and simplest answer choice that expresses the same idea is almost always correct—if anything is redundant, wordy, or irrelevant, eliminate it.

1. Redundancy

  • Redundancy occurs when information is unnecessarily repeated
    • Read the sentence itself AND the sentence(s) before to check for repeated information
    • If two words or phrases mean the same thing, one must be removed
  • Common redundant phrases to watch for
    • ❌ "Returned back" → ✓ "Returned" (returning already means coming back)
    • ❌ "In the Swedish forests" when Sweden was already mentioned → ✓ "In the forests"
    • ❌ "Past history" → ✓ "History" (history is always past)
    • ❌ "Free gift" → ✓ "Gift" (gifts are free by definition)

Example: Context-Based Redundancy

  • ❌ Incorrect: "In Sweden, there are about 300,000 to 400,000 moose, many of which stand over seven feet tall, roaming freely in the Swedish forests."
  • ✓ Correct: "In Sweden, there are about 300,000 to 400,000 moose, many of which stand over 7 feet tall, roaming freely in the forests."
  • Why: The sentence already specifies the moose are in Sweden, so "Swedish" is redundant

2. Wordiness

  • Sentences can be unnecessarily wordy without being redundant
    • Pick the answer choice that uses the fewest words to express the same idea
    • Eliminate flowery or unnecessarily complex language
  • Common wordy phrases and their concise alternatives
    • ❌ "Due to the fact that" → ✓ "Because"
    • ❌ "At this point in time" → ✓ "Now"
    • ❌ "In the event that" → ✓ "If"
    • ❌ "A cultural institution supporting intellectual endeavors related to renaissance art" → ✓ "A museum devoted to renaissance art"

Example: Simplifying Wordy Phrases

  • ❌ Incorrect: "The ancient Italian sculptures were donated to a cultural institution supporting intellectual endeavors related to renaissance art."
  • ✓ Correct: "The ancient Italian sculptures were donated to a museum devoted to renaissance art."
  • Why: The simpler version conveys the exact same meaning with far fewer words

3. Irrelevance

  • Irrelevant information doesn't contribute to the passage's main idea or current paragraph
    • Irrelevant details most often appear as long, wordy answer choices
    • These answer choices are always incorrect
    • Ask: Does this information help tell the story or explain the concept?

Example: Removing Irrelevant Details

  • ❌ Incorrect: "To win the game, Ricky needed to make both free throws. Players are not allowed to step in the lane during a free throw attempt. He made the first one. The entire gym was quiet as he stepped to the line for the second."
  • ✓ Correct: "To win the game, Ricky needed to make both free throws. He made the first one. The entire gym was quiet as he stepped to the line for the second."
  • Why: The rule about stepping in the lane is irrelevant to Ricky's specific free throw situation

4. How to Spot These Questions

  • The ACT directly tells you when testing redundancy, wordiness, or irrelevance
    • Look for questions asking: "Which choice is the least redundant in context?"
    • Or: "Which choice best avoids wordiness and redundancy in context?"
    • When you see these questions, the shortest answer is almost always correct
  • Important warning: ONLY use "shortest is correct" for these specific questions
    • On grammar questions (not asking about redundancy), the shortest answer may be wrong
    • Example: An ambiguous pronoun like "it" or "them" might be shortest but incorrect
    • Always apply grammar rules first unless the question specifically asks about redundancy

Recognizing Ambiguous Pronouns

  • Even though pronouns are short, they're incorrect if ambiguous
    • Watch for: they, them, it, this, that, these, those, some, none
    • If you can't tell exactly what the pronoun refers to, it's incorrect
    • Example: "Freddie ordered some" is ambiguous—some what? Coral? Aquariums?
    • Correct: "Freddie ordered some coral colonies" clearly specifies what he ordered

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Redundancy occurs when information is unnecessarily repeated—check the current sentence and previous sentences for duplicate information. Common examples: "returned back" (just "returned"), "Swedish forests" when Sweden was already mentioned (just "the forests").
  • ✓Wordiness means using more words than necessary to express an idea. Pick the answer choice with the fewest words that conveys the same meaning: "because" instead of "due to the fact that," "museum" instead of "cultural institution supporting intellectual endeavors."
  • ✓Irrelevant information doesn't contribute to the passage's main idea or current paragraph—these details often appear as long, wordy answer choices and are always incorrect. Ask yourself: does this information help tell the story or explain the concept?
  • ✓The ACT directly asks "Which choice is the least redundant in context?" or "Which choice best avoids wordiness?" For THESE questions only, the shortest answer is almost always correct. However, on grammar questions, don't always pick the shortest—ambiguous pronouns (it, them, some) may be short but incorrect.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.2 - Word Choice
lessons.content:
Word choice questions appear on the ACT English Test and ask you to select the word that is clearest and most precise in context. These questions test your ability to read for context and choose the word that best conveys the intended meaning of the sentence.

1. Identifying Word Choice Questions

  • Word choice questions always have 4 words with no punctuation or the same punctuation
    • The question asks: "Which choice is clearest and most precise in context?"
    • All choices are grammatically correct
    • You must select the word that best fits the meaning and tone
  • These questions test both vocabulary and context
    • Some test word definitions (knowing what words mean)
    • Others test which word makes the most sense in this specific sentence
    • Context is always the key to finding the right answer

2. How to Approach Word Choice Questions

  • Follow this three-step process
    • Step 1: Read the sentence and surrounding sentences for context
    • Step 2: Plug each word into the sentence one at a time
    • Step 3: Pick the word that makes the most sense in context
  • Context includes both meaning and tone
    • Does the word's definition fit logically?
    • Does the word's formality level match the passage?
    • Does it create the intended relationship between ideas?

Example Approach

  • Question: "Adding solar panels to your house can emit huge savings on energy bills."
    • A. emit
    • B. claim
    • C. gift
    • D. result in
  • Analysis
    • "Emit" means to send out or release—doesn't fit with savings
    • "Claim" means to assert or demand—doesn't make sense here
    • "Gift" is a noun, not a verb that fits this context
    • "Result in" means to cause or produce—this fits perfectly!
  • The answer is D because "result in" is the only phrase that logically completes the meaning

3. Vocabulary Strategy

  • Don't assume the hardest word is correct
    • Sometimes the ACT includes challenging vocabulary you need to know
    • Other times, challenging words are incorrect answer choices
    • The difficulty level of the word doesn't indicate if it's right or wrong
  • What to do when you don't know a word
    • If you know a word works, pick it—even if it seems easy
    • Eliminate words you know are wrong
    • If you don't know a word and have to guess, make your best guess and move on
    • Don't spend too much time on vocabulary you don't know

Trust What You Know

  • Your instinct about common words is usually correct
    • If a simple word like "make" or "show" fits perfectly, it's likely correct
    • Don't overthink or assume you need a fancier word
    • The ACT values precision and clarity, not complexity

4. Common Word Choice Patterns

  • Similar-sounding words with different meanings
    • Affect (verb - to influence) vs. Effect (noun - result)
    • Elicit (to draw out) vs. Illicit (illegal)
    • Complement (to complete) vs. Compliment (to praise)
  • Words with similar meanings but different connotations
    • Dispassionate (unemotional) vs. Disinterested (unbiased) vs. Unbiased (neutral)
    • Display (to show) vs. Reveal (to uncover) vs. Exhibit (to demonstrate)
    • Context determines which shade of meaning is correct
  • Phrasal verbs and preposition choices
    • "Improved over" vs. "improved upon" vs. "improved above"
    • The correct preposition changes the meaning
    • Trust what sounds natural in standard English

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Word choice questions ask "Which choice is clearest and most precise in context?" and provide 4 words with the same punctuation. All choices are grammatically correct, so you must select based on meaning and context, not grammar rules.
  • ✓Use the three-step approach: (1) Read the sentence and surrounding context, (2) Plug each word into the sentence, (3) Pick the word that makes the most sense. Consider both the word's definition and whether its formality level matches the passage.
  • ✓Don't assume the hardest vocabulary word is correct—sometimes challenging words are wrong answers. If you know a simple word works, pick it even if it seems easy. The ACT values precision and clarity over complexity.
  • ✓Watch for similar-sounding words with different meanings (affect/effect, elicit/illicit), words with similar meanings but different connotations (dispassionate/disinterested), and phrasal verbs where the preposition matters ("improved over" vs. "improved above").

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.3 - Transitions
lessons.content:
Transition questions test your reading comprehension by asking you to select the word or phrase that best connects ideas between sentences. All answer choices will be grammatically correct, so you must read for context to determine which transition logically relates the ideas.

1. How to Approach Transition Questions

  • Follow this three-step process
    • Step 1: Ignore the transition currently in the passage—cover it up
    • Step 2: Read the sentence(s) before and after to determine their relationship
    • Step 3: Select the transition that correctly relates the ideas
  • Context is everything
    • You cannot determine the correct transition by reading only one sentence
    • Always read both the previous and following sentences
    • Ask: What is the relationship between these ideas?

2. Type 1: All Four Choices Are Transitions

  • When all 4 answer choices are transitions, you're only being tested on selecting the correct one
    • Read for context to understand the relationship
    • Match the transition to the logical connection between ideas

Example

  • "From a distance, the ocean looked pretty calm today even though a storm had arrived last night. Under the circumstances, the scene was much more chaotic with big waves and strong riptides."
    • A. NO CHANGE (Under the circumstances)
    • B. For instance
    • C. Up close
    • D. For example
  • ✓ Correct: C. "Up close" creates a contrast with "from a distance" in the previous sentence

3. Type 2: Three Transitions and One "No Transition" Option

  • When one choice has no transition, the ACT is asking whether a transition is even necessary
    • Most often, the correct answer is the one that removes the transition entirely
    • Only use a transition if it properly links the sentences
    • If the ideas flow naturally without a transition, choose the "no transition" option

When to Remove Transitions

  • Remove the transition if:
    • The sentences are simply continuing the same idea
    • The relationship is already clear without a transition word
    • Adding a transition makes the connection awkward or incorrect

4. Common Transition Categories

  • Contrast/Opposition: However, Nevertheless, On the other hand, In contrast, Despite this
  • Example/Illustration: For example, For instance, Specifically, In particular
  • Cause/Effect: Therefore, Consequently, As a result, Thus, Hence
  • Addition: Furthermore, Moreover, Additionally, In addition, Also
  • Time Sequence: Meanwhile, Subsequently, Previously, Ultimately, Finally
  • Emphasis: Indeed, In fact, Certainly, Undoubtedly

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Use the three-step approach: (1) Ignore the current transition, (2) Read sentences before and after to determine their relationship, (3) Select the transition that correctly connects the ideas. You cannot determine the correct transition by reading only one sentence.
  • ✓When all 4 choices are transitions, you're choosing which relationship is correct (contrast, example, cause/effect, addition, etc.). When 3 choices are transitions and 1 has no transition, consider whether a transition is even necessary—most often, the correct answer removes the transition entirely.
  • ✓Remove transitions when sentences simply continue the same idea, the relationship is already clear, or adding a transition makes the connection awkward. Only use a transition if it properly links the sentences and clarifies the relationship between ideas.
  • ✓Know the main transition categories: Contrast (However, Nevertheless), Example (For instance, Specifically), Cause/Effect (Therefore, Consequently), Addition (Furthermore, Moreover), Time (Meanwhile, Subsequently), and Emphasis (Indeed, In fact).

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.4 - Which Choice Questions
lessons.content:
"Which choice" questions ask you to make specific changes to a sentence, and the question itself tells you exactly what to do. These questions are easy to spot—they always include the words "which choice" or "which one" in the question.

1. How to Identify and Approach These Questions

  • Easy to spot: Look for "which choice" or "which one" in the question
    • The question tells you exactly what change to make
    • All answer choices are usually grammatically correct
  • Your job: Figure out what the question asks and do exactly that
    • Don't worry about grammar, conciseness, or style unless the question specifically asks
    • Shorter is NOT always better on these questions
    • Just answer the question—don't overthink it!

2. Type 1: Specific Detail Questions

  • These ask you to provide or emphasize a specific detail
    • Common phrasing: "most specifically describes," "most clearly emphasizes," "provides the most relevant detail"
    • Focus on the sentence you're editing
    • Read sentences before and after for context, but don't rely on them too heavily

Example: Specific Description

  • Question: "Which choice most specifically describes what was used to build iceboxes?"
  • Context: "Americans kept their food cold in iceboxes, which required ice to be bought and placed into the box each week."
    • A. NO CHANGE
    • B. which were only cold enough to keep food cool but not freeze anything
    • C. wooden boxes with tin and insulated with cork and sawdust
    • D. the very first invention that allowed people to keep food cold
  • ✓ Answer: C—it's the only choice that describes the materials used to build iceboxes

3. Type 2: Emphasis and Tone Questions

  • These ask you to emphasize a particular aspect or create a certain tone
    • Common phrasing: "most clearly emphasizes," "best conveys," "creates the most vivid image"
    • Focus on which word choice highlights the specific quality mentioned

Example: Emphasis

  • Question: "Which choice most clearly emphasizes how the dinosaurs increase in size?"
  • Context: "Harold always begged for grow-in-water dinosaurs that sprawl when placed into water."
    • A. NO CHANGE (sprawl)
    • B. change in size
    • C. expand
    • D. soak
  • ✓ Answer: C—"expand" most clearly emphasizes the size increase

4. Common Question Phrasings

  • Questions asking for specific details
    • "Which choice most specifically describes..."
    • "Which choice provides the most relevant detail about..."
    • "Which choice best supports the claim that..."
  • Questions asking for emphasis or tone
    • "Which choice most clearly emphasizes..."
    • "Which choice best conveys..."
    • "Which choice creates the most vivid image of..."
  • The key strategy: Read the question carefully and give it exactly what it asks for—nothing more, nothing less

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓"Which choice" questions are easy to spot—they always include "which choice" or "which one" in the question. Your job is to figure out exactly what the question asks and select the answer that does that specific thing, not to fix grammar or improve style.
  • ✓All answer choices are usually grammatically correct, so don't worry about grammar unless the question specifically asks about it. Shorter is NOT always better on these questions—choose the answer that best fulfills the specific request.
  • ✓Specific detail questions ask for information about a particular aspect (materials, location, time, etc.). Choose the answer that provides that specific detail, even if other answers are more concise or sound better.
  • ✓Emphasis and tone questions ask you to highlight a particular quality or create a certain feeling. Focus on which word choice best emphasizes the specific aspect mentioned in the question—don't overthink it, just answer what's asked!

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.5 - Adding or Deleting Information
lessons.content:
Adding or deleting information questions ask whether specific information should be included in a passage or not. For these questions, you must read for context—we recommend reading the entire paragraph where the question appears to determine if the information fits.

1. How to Approach These Questions

  • Read the paragraph twice: once with the information included and once with it deleted
    • This makes it clear whether the information should be included
    • Consider: Does the information fit the paragraph's focus?
    • Depending on the question, you may need to read more than one paragraph
  • Context is critical
    • You must understand what the paragraph is discussing
    • The information should support or relate to the main idea

2. Adding Information Questions

  • These questions give you a sentence or phrase and ask if it should be added
    • Answer choices have two parts: (1) Yes or No, (2) Justification why
    • First decide yes or no, then pick the correct justification

Critical Strategy: Only Consider What the Sentence Says

  • When evaluating justifications, only consider the sentence being added
    • Many students pick justifications that go far beyond what the sentence says
    • Don't include details that have nothing to do with the sentence itself
    • The justification must accurately describe what that specific sentence provides

Example Structure

  • Question: "Should the writer add this sentence about Dr. Anderson's education?"
    • A. Yes, because it establishes Dr. Paul's mentor's qualifications
    • B. Yes, because it indicates Dr. Anderson had a top-notch education
    • C. No, because it does not indicate where Dr. Paul studied
    • D. No, because it is not relevant to the passage's discussion of Dr. Paul's career
  • If the passage is about Dr. Paul's career, not his mentor's, the answer is D

3. Deleting Information Questions

  • These ask if existing information should be removed
    • Same format: Yes/No + Justification
    • Consider whether the information is relevant and necessary

When to Delete Information

  • Delete when the information:
    • Is irrelevant to the paragraph's main idea
    • Repeats information already stated
    • Distracts from the paragraph's focus
    • Doesn't add anything meaningful
  • Keep when the information:
    • Supports the main idea
    • Provides necessary detail or clarification
    • Connects ideas within the paragraph

4. Common Answer Choice Patterns

  • Good justifications are specific and accurate
    • They describe exactly what the sentence provides
    • They relate to the paragraph's focus
    • Example: "provides specific detail about the location" (if the sentence actually does that)
  • Bad justifications are vague or go too far
    • They claim the sentence says more than it actually does
    • They focus on irrelevant details
    • Example: "proves the scientist was the best in his field" (when sentence only mentions one achievement)

Common Wrong Answer Traps

  • Watch out for justifications that:
    • Reference information NOT in the sentence being added/deleted
    • Make logical leaps beyond what the sentence states
    • Focus on the wrong person, topic, or idea
    • Use absolute language ("proves," "always," "never") when the sentence is less definitive

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Read the paragraph twice—once with the information included and once with it deleted. This approach makes it clear whether the information fits the paragraph's focus and supports the main idea. Context is critical, so understand what the paragraph is discussing before deciding.
  • ✓Answer choices have two parts: (1) Yes or No, (2) Justification. First decide yes or no, then pick the correct justification. The justification must accurately describe what the specific sentence provides—don't pick options that go beyond what the sentence actually says.
  • ✓Delete information when it's irrelevant to the main idea, repeats what's already stated, or distracts from the paragraph's focus. Keep information when it supports the main idea, provides necessary detail, or connects ideas within the paragraph.
  • ✓Avoid justifications that reference information NOT in the sentence, make logical leaps, focus on the wrong topic, or use absolute language when the sentence is less definitive. Good justifications are specific, accurate, and describe exactly what the sentence provides.

lessons.subject: english
lessons.title: Topic 2.6 - Logical Placement
lessons.content:
Logical placement questions ask you to place a sentence in the paragraph based on context and logical flow. These questions test your ability to recognize where information fits best by reading the sentences before and after each potential placement spot.

1. How to Identify These Questions

  • Logical placement questions are easy to spot because they always ask where to place a sentence
    • Common phrasing: "For the sake of logic and coherence, Sentence X should be placed..."
    • Or: "The sentence would most logically be placed..."
  • Look for bracketed numbers [1] [2] [3] at the beginning of sentences
    • Bracketed numbers only appear when there's a logical placement question
    • Read these paragraphs more carefully—they may currently be out of order
    • The paragraph may seem confusing at first because sentences are misplaced
  • Bracketed letters [A] [B] [C] appear for end-of-passage placement questions
    • Don't worry about the letters while reading—just note there will be a placement question
    • The question will ask where to place a new sentence in the passage

2. The Critical Strategy: Plug and Read

  • To find the correct answer, plug the sentence into each potential spot and re-read
    • Don't just read the sentence before the placement—this is the most common mistake
    • You MUST read the sentence(s) before AND after where you're placing it
    • The correct placement should flow smoothly in both directions

Step-by-Step Approach

  • Step 1: Read the entire paragraph first to understand the overall context
    • Even if it seems confusing, get a sense of the topic and flow
    • Identify what the paragraph is discussing
  • Step 2: Identify the sentence you need to place
    • What specific information does it contain?
    • What does it refer to or connect to?
  • Step 3: Test each answer choice by plugging in the sentence
    • Read from the sentence before → through the placed sentence → to the sentence after
    • Does it create smooth, logical flow?
    • Do pronouns have clear references?
    • Does the information follow a logical sequence?

3. What Makes a Placement Correct

  • The correct placement creates logical flow and coherence
    • Information should follow a natural, chronological, or logical order
    • Pronouns should refer to clearly established nouns
    • Transition words should make sense in context

Look for These Clues

  • Pronouns and references
    • If the sentence says "This ultimately resulted in..." it must come after what caused the result
    • If it says "he" or "she," the person must be introduced before
    • Words like "this," "that," "these," "those" refer back to previously mentioned concepts
  • Chronological order
    • Events should follow time order unless context suggests otherwise
    • Time markers like "first," "then," "after," "before" help establish sequence
  • Topic continuity
    • Sentences discussing the same subtopic should be grouped together
    • Don't interrupt one idea with an unrelated sentence
  • Transition words and phrases
    • "However," "in contrast," "on the other hand" signal a shift or contrast
    • "For example," "such as" provide examples of previous statements
    • "Further," "additionally," "moreover" add to previous points

4. Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • Not reading the sentence AFTER the placement
    • This is the #1 mistake students make
    • You must check that the sentence flows into what comes next
    • A sentence might connect well to what comes before but not to what comes after
  • Not reading the entire paragraph first
    • You need context to understand where the sentence fits
    • Without reading the whole paragraph, you might miss important clues
  • Choosing based on topic similarity alone
    • Just because two sentences discuss the same topic doesn't mean they belong together
    • Check for logical sequence and smooth transitions
  • Rushing through the answer choices
    • Take time to actually plug in the sentence at each spot
    • Read the surrounding sentences carefully for each option

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Logical placement questions ask "where should this sentence be placed?" Look for bracketed numbers [1] [2] [3] at the beginning of sentences—these only appear when there's a logical placement question. Read these paragraphs carefully as they may currently be out of order.
  • ✓The critical strategy: plug the sentence into each potential spot and re-read the sentences before AND after. Many students only read before the placement—this is the #1 mistake! The correct placement must flow smoothly in both directions.
  • ✓Look for clues: pronouns and references (words like "this," "that," "he," "she" must refer to something previously mentioned), chronological order (events follow time sequence), topic continuity (related ideas stay together), and transition words ("however," "for example," "additionally").
  • ✓Read the entire paragraph first to understand context, then test each answer choice by actually plugging in the sentence at each spot. Don't choose based on topic similarity alone—check for logical sequence, smooth transitions, and clear pronoun references.

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Areas, Volumes & Triangles
lessons.content:
Geometry questions involving areas, volumes, and triangles appear on every ACT Math test, accounting for approximately 15-20% of all questions. Success on these problems requires memorizing key formulas and knowing when to apply specific triangle rules like Pythagorean theorem and special right triangle ratios.

1. Area Formulas for Common Shapes

  • You MUST memorize these area formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT:
    • Triangle: A = ½bh (where b = base, h = height)
    • Rectangle: A = lw (where l = length, w = width)
    • Square: A = s² (where s = side length)
    • Parallelogram: A = bh (base times height, NOT side lengths)
    • Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h (average of the two bases times height)
    • Circle: A = πr² (where r = radius)
    • Kite: A = ½d₁d₂ (half the product of the diagonals)
  • Common mistakes to avoid:
    • For parallelograms, use the HEIGHT (perpendicular distance), not the slanted side length
    • For circles, make sure you have the radius, not the diameter (if given diameter, divide by 2)
    • For triangles, the height must be perpendicular to the base
  • Perimeter formulas you should know:
    • Rectangle: P = 2l + 2w
    • Square: P = 4s
    • Circle (circumference): C = 2πr or C = πd

2. Volume Formulas and Unit Conversions

  • Essential volume formulas to memorize:
    • Rectangular Prism (box): V = lwh
    • Cube: V = s³
    • Right Cylinder: V = πr²h
    • Any 3D shape: V = Bh (where B = area of base, h = height)
  • Surface area formulas (less common but important):
    • Rectangular Prism: SA = 2lw + 2lh + 2wh
    • Cube: SA = 6s²
  • CRITICAL: Unit conversions—The ACT frequently tests these, and students make costly mistakes:
    • Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume
    • 1 yard = 3 feet
    • 1 foot = 12 inches
    • 1 square yard = 9 square feet (not 3!)
    • 1 square foot = 144 square inches (not 12!)
    • 1 cubic yard = 27 cubic feet (not 3!)
    • 1 cubic foot = 1,728 cubic inches (not 12!)
  • Why you must convert FIRST:
    • Example: A field is 136 yards × 93 yards. To find area in square feet:
    • ✓ CORRECT: Convert to feet first: (136 × 3) × (93 × 3) = 408 × 279 = 113,832 ft²
    • ✗ WRONG: Calculate area then convert: 136 × 93 = 12,648, then × 9 = wrong answer!

3. Right Triangles and Pythagorean Theorem

  • The Pythagorean theorem applies ONLY to right triangles:
    • a² + b² = c²
    • Where a and b are the legs (the two shorter sides)
    • c is the hypotenuse (the longest side, opposite the right angle)
  • Pythagorean triples—memorize these to save time:
    • 3-4-5 triangle: If you see sides of 3 and 4, the hypotenuse is 5
    • 5-12-13 triangle: If you see sides of 5 and 12, the hypotenuse is 13
    • These can be scaled up: 6-8-10, 9-12-15, 10-24-26, etc.
    • If you recognize a Pythagorean triple, you can skip the calculation entirely
  • When to use Pythagorean theorem:
    • Finding the third side of a right triangle when you know two sides
    • Finding distances in coordinate geometry problems
    • Solving problems with rectangles (diagonals create right triangles)
    • Working with circles and tangent lines

4. Special Right Triangles (30-60-90 and 45-45-90)

  • 45-45-90 triangle (also called a right isosceles triangle):
    • Side ratio: x : x : x√2
    • The two legs are equal (both length x)
    • The hypotenuse is x√2 (one leg times √2)
    • If the leg is 5, the hypotenuse is 5√2
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, each leg is 10/√2 = 5√2
  • 30-60-90 triangle:
    • Side ratio: x : x√3 : 2x
    • Short leg (opposite 30°): x
    • Long leg (opposite 60°): x√3
    • Hypotenuse (opposite 90°): 2x
    • KEY RULE: The short leg is always half the hypotenuse
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, the short leg is 5, and the long leg is 5√3
  • How to recognize special right triangles:
    • Look for angle measurements (45°, 30°, 60°)
    • Look for the phrase "right isosceles triangle" (45-45-90)
    • Look for equilateral triangles split in half (creates 30-60-90)
    • If you see √2 or √3 in the answer choices, it's likely a special right triangle
  • When to use special right triangles instead of Pythagorean theorem:
    • When you see the special angles (30°, 45°, 60°)
    • When the answer choices contain √2 or √3
    • Special triangles are FASTER than using a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Geometry Problems

  • Draw and label diagrams
    • If no diagram is provided, draw one yourself
    • Label all given measurements directly on the diagram
    • Mark right angles with a small square
    • Write formulas next to the shapes as you work
  • Look for Pythagorean triples first
    • Before using a² + b² = c², check if the sides are a Pythagorean triple
    • Common ones: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, and their multiples
    • This saves time and prevents calculation errors
  • Use substitution for complex problems
    • If a problem uses variables (like "a field is l feet by w feet"), pick simple numbers
    • Example: Let l = 4 and w = 3, then solve with those specific values
    • This makes algebraic area/volume problems much easier to visualize
  • Convert units before calculating
    • NEVER calculate area in yards and then convert to square feet
    • ALWAYS convert the length and width first, then calculate
    • Write out the conversion as a separate step to avoid mistakes
  • Memorize formulas NOW, not the night before
    • Make flashcards for all area and volume formulas
    • Practice drawing and labeling 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 triangles from memory
    • Review Pythagorean triples until you can recognize them instantly

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Memorize all area and volume formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT, and you must know them cold to save time
  • ✓Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume (1 square yard = 9 square feet, NOT 3)
  • ✓Recognize Pythagorean triples (3-4-5, 5-12-13) and special right triangles (45-45-90 ratio x:x:x√2, 30-60-90 ratio x:x√3:2x) to solve problems instantly
  • ✓For Pythagorean theorem, remember a² + b² = c² only works for right triangles, where c is always the hypotenuse (longest side)

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Lines
lessons.content:
Lines and linear functions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, testing your ability to calculate slope, write equations, and use coordinate geometry formulas. Mastering the different forms of linear equations and understanding parallel/perpendicular relationships is essential for scoring well on these questions.

1. Slope and Its Properties

  • Slope formula for any two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):
    • Slope = (y₁ - y₂) / (x₁ - x₂) = rise / run
    • Rise = change in y-coordinates
    • Run = change in x-coordinates
  • Understanding slope values:
    • Positive slope: Line goes up and to the right
    • Negative slope: Line goes down and to the right
    • Higher slope: Steeper line
    • Lower slope: Flatter line
    • Zero slope: Horizontal line
    • Undefined slope: Vertical line
  • Parallel lines: Same slope
    • If line A has slope 3, any line parallel to it also has slope 3
    • Parallel lines never intersect
  • Perpendicular lines: Slopes are negative reciprocals
    • To find the negative reciprocal: flip the fraction and change the sign
    • If line A has slope 2/3, a perpendicular line has slope -3/2
    • If line A has slope 4, a perpendicular line has slope -1/4
    • If line A has slope -5, a perpendicular line has slope 1/5
    • Perpendicular lines intersect at 90 degrees

2. Slope-Intercept Form (y = mx + b)

  • The most common and useful form of a linear equation:
    • y = mx + b
    • m = slope (steepness of the line)
    • b = y-intercept (where the line crosses the y-axis)
  • Reading information from the equation:
    • Example: y = 3x - 5 has slope 3 and y-intercept -5
    • Example: y = -2x + 7 has slope -2 and y-intercept 7
    • Example: y = (1/2)x + 4 has slope 1/2 and y-intercept 4
  • Reading information from a graph:
    • Find the y-intercept: where the line crosses the y-axis
    • Find the slope: pick two points and calculate rise/run
    • Or count: "up 2, right 1" means slope = 2/1 = 2
  • When to use slope-intercept form:
    • When you know the slope and y-intercept
    • When you need to quickly identify slope or y-intercept from an equation
    • When graphing a line

3. Point-Slope Form and Standard Form

  • Point-slope form: Use when you know a point and the slope
    • y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)
    • (x₁, y₁) is a point on the line
    • m is the slope
    • After plugging in values, solve for y to convert to slope-intercept form
  • Alternative method: Plug point into y = mx + b
    • If you know the slope m, write: y = mx + b
    • Plug in the (x, y) values of a point on the line
    • Solve for b to find the y-intercept
    • This often feels more intuitive than point-slope form
  • Standard form: Less common but sometimes useful
    • Ax + By = C
    • A, B, and C are constants (usually integers)
    • To find slope from standard form: slope = -A/B
    • To find y-intercept: set x = 0 and solve for y
    • To find x-intercept: set y = 0 and solve for x
    • Usually easier to convert to slope-intercept form first

4. Midpoint and Distance Formulas

  • Midpoint formula: Finds the point exactly halfway between two points
    • Midpoint = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)
    • Average the x-coordinates, average the y-coordinates
    • Example: Midpoint of (2, 5) and (8, 13) = ((2+8)/2, (5+13)/2) = (5, 9)
  • Distance formula: Finds the straight-line distance between two points
    • Distance = √[(x₁ - x₂)² + (y₁ - y₂)²]
    • This is the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates
    • (x₁ - x₂) is the horizontal distance
    • (y₁ - y₂) is the vertical distance
    • Square both, add them, then take the square root
  • Relationship between distance and Pythagorean theorem:
    • The distance formula IS the Pythagorean theorem
    • The two points form a right triangle with legs (x₁ - x₂) and (y₁ - y₂)
    • The distance is the hypotenuse
    • Sometimes it's easier to draw the triangle and use a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Line Questions

  • Always convert to y = mx + b when possible
    • Slope-intercept form is the easiest to work with
    • If given standard form, solve for y immediately
    • If given point-slope form, distribute and solve for y
  • For perpendicular lines, flip and negate the slope
    • Perpendicular slope = -1 / (original slope)
    • If slope is 2, perpendicular is -1/2
    • If slope is -3/4, perpendicular is 4/3
  • Use substitution to verify equations
    • If given a point and asked which equation represents the line, plug the point into each answer choice
    • The correct equation will make the point satisfy the equation
    • This can be faster than calculating slope and y-intercept
  • Draw quick sketches for visual problems
    • If given two points, plot them quickly on scratch paper
    • Visualize the slope (is it positive or negative? steep or flat?)
    • This helps catch sign errors and eliminate wrong answers
  • Memorize the formulas
    • Slope formula, midpoint formula, and distance formula must be memorized
    • They are NOT provided on the ACT
    • Practice writing them from memory until automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Parallel lines have the same slope, perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes (flip fraction and change sign)
  • ✓Always convert equations to y = mx + b form when possible—it makes finding slope and y-intercept immediate
  • ✓Memorize: slope = (y₁-y₂)/(x₁-x₂), midpoint = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2), distance = √[(x₁-x₂)² + (y₁-y₂)²]
  • ✓The distance formula is just the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates—sometimes it's easier to draw the right triangle

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Arcs and Sectors
lessons.content:
Arcs and sectors appear occasionally on the ACT Math test, usually 1-2 questions per test. These problems test your understanding of how parts of a circle relate to the whole circle using proportional reasoning with central angles.

1. Understanding Arcs

  • An arc is a portion of a circle's circumference
    • Think of it as a "slice" of the circle's edge
    • Arcs are measured in two ways: degree measure or arc length
  • Degree measure of an arc:
    • Equal to the measure of the central angle that intercepts it
    • A central angle is an angle whose vertex is at the center of the circle
    • Example: If the central angle is 90°, the arc measures 90°
  • Arc length (the actual distance along the curve):
    • Arc length is a portion of the total circumference
    • Use the proportion: arc length / circumference = angle / 360°
  • Arc length formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Arc Length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • 2πr = circumference of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (same formula):
    • Arc Length / Circumference = θ / 360°
    • This proportion shows: arc is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
    • Useful when you need to solve for the angle or radius

2. Understanding Sectors

  • A sector is a "slice" of a circle (like a pizza slice)
    • Bounded by two radii and an arc
    • Sectors have area, just like the whole circle has area
  • Sector area formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Sector Area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • πr² = area of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (proportion):
    • Sector Area / Circle Area = θ / 360°
    • This shows: sector is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
  • Key pattern to recognize:
    • Arc length uses circumference (2πr)
    • Sector area uses circle area (πr²)
    • Both use the same proportion: (θ/360°)

3. Solving Arc and Sector Problems

  • Step-by-step approach for arc length:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circumference: 2πr
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
  • Step-by-step approach for sector area:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circle area: πr²
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
  • Working backwards (finding angle or radius):
    • If given arc length and radius, solve for θ
    • If given sector area and angle, solve for r
    • Use algebra to isolate the unknown variable
  • Common question types:
    • Given angle and radius, find arc length or sector area
    • Given arc length and radius, find the central angle
    • Given sector area and angle, find the radius
    • Finding the difference between two arcs or sectors

4. Test-Taking Tips for Arcs and Sectors

  • Think in terms of proportions
    • The key insight: the arc/sector is a fraction of the whole circle
    • That fraction equals the central angle divided by 360°
    • Example: A 90° angle means 90/360 = 1/4 of the circle
  • Don't confuse arc length with sector area
    • Arc length is distance (1-dimensional) - uses circumference
    • Sector area is space (2-dimensional) - uses circle area
    • Read the question carefully to determine which one is asked
  • Memorize the formulas now
    • Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • These are NOT provided on the test
  • Use the proportion setup for complex problems
    • Arc/Circumference = Angle/360° is easier to manipulate algebraically
    • Especially useful when solving for the angle or radius
    • Cross-multiply to solve
  • Simplify the fraction θ/360° early
    • 90/360 = 1/4, 120/360 = 1/3, 180/360 = 1/2
    • This makes calculations much simpler
    • Example: (90/360) × 2π(12) = (1/4) × 24π = 6π

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr and Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²—these formulas are NOT provided on the ACT
  • ✓The central angle determines what fraction of the circle you have: a 90° angle = 1/4 of the circle
  • ✓Arc length is 1-dimensional (uses circumference 2πr), sector area is 2-dimensional (uses circle area πr²)
  • ✓Think proportionally: arc/circumference = sector/circle = angle/360°—this relationship solves all arc and sector problems

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Logarithms
lessons.content:
Logarithms appear 1-2 times per ACT Math test, usually testing your ability to convert between logarithmic form and exponential form. Understanding this conversion is the key to solving almost all logarithm questions on the ACT.

1. Basics of Logarithms (Converting Between Forms)

  • The fundamental relationship between logs and exponents:
    • log_a(b) = c is the same as a^c = b
    • Where a is the base, c is the exponent, and b is the result
    • Both equations describe the exact same relationship—just different notation
  • Examples of converting from logarithmic form to exponential form:
    • log₃(3) = 1 → 3¹ = 3
    • log₃(9) = 2 → 3² = 9
    • log₃(27) = 3 → 3³ = 27
    • The pattern: "log base 3 of 27 equals 3" means "3 to the 3rd power equals 27"
  • How to solve logarithm equations:
    • Step 1: Convert from logarithmic form to exponential form
    • Step 2: Solve the exponential equation using exponent rules
    • Example: When log₄(x) = 3, what is x?
    • Convert: 4³ = x
    • Solve: x = 64
  • CRITICAL strategy:
    • Almost ALL ACT logarithm questions are solved by converting to exponential form
    • If you can convert, you can solve the problem
    • Practice this conversion until it's automatic!

2. Using Your Calculator (Change of Base Rule)

  • The change of base rule lets you use a calculator:
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b)
    • This converts ANY logarithm to base 10 (which calculators can compute)
    • Example: log₃(9) = log(9) / log(3) = 0.954 / 0.477 = 2
  • Using the change of base rule on your calculator:
    • To find log₃(9): Enter log(9) ÷ log(3) in calculator
    • To find log₂(8): Enter log(8) ÷ log(2) in calculator
    • This works for ANY base and ANY value
  • Some calculators have a built-in logbase function:
    • TI-83/84: Press MATH, scroll to LOGBASE
    • This allows direct entry: logbase(3, 9) = 2
    • Check if your calculator has this feature—it's faster!
  • Calculator method vs. algebraic method:
    • For simple bases (2, 3, 4, 5): Converting to exponential form is often faster
    • For complex problems with multiple logs: Use change of base rule
    • Example: 5(log₃(9) + log₂(8)) can be solved entirely with calculator

3. Logarithm Rules (For Advanced Questions)

  • Four logarithm rules you should know:
    • Product Rule: log_a(xy) = log_a(x) + log_a(y)
    • Quotient Rule: log_a(x/y) = log_a(x) - log_a(y)
    • Power Rule: log_a(x^n) = n·log_a(x)
    • Log of 1: log_a(1) = 0 (because a⁰ = 1)
  • When to use these rules:
    • These appear RARELY on the ACT (1-2 times per test, if at all)
    • Most often on the LAST 10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students aiming for 30+ should memorize these
    • Other students can skip—focus on conversion first!
  • Example using power rule:
    • If log₉(3^x) = 3/2, what is x?
    • Use power rule: x·log₉(3) = 3/2
    • Find log₉(3) using change of base: log(3)/log(9) = 1/2
    • Substitute: x·(1/2) = 3/2
    • Solve: x = 3
  • Shortcut - backsolving with calculator:
    • If answer choices are given, plug each one in
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate both sides
    • The correct answer makes both sides equal
    • This is often faster than using logarithm rules!

4. Natural Logarithms (ln)

  • Natural logarithms use base e (approximately 2.71828):
    • ln(b) = c is the same as e^c = b
    • The base "e" is invisible—it's always e for natural logs
    • ln is just shorthand notation for log_e
  • Natural logarithms appear VERY rarely:
    • Usually only in the last 5-10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students rushing through can skip this topic entirely
    • Students aiming for 30+ should learn the basics
  • Solving natural logarithm equations:
    • Example: If ln(x-1) = 3, then x = ?
    • Step 1: Convert to exponential form: e³ = x-1
    • Step 2: Solve for x: x = e³ + 1
    • Same conversion strategy as regular logarithms!
  • All logarithm rules work for natural logs too:
    • ln(xy) = ln(x) + ln(y)
    • ln(x/y) = ln(x) - ln(y)
    • ln(x^n) = n·ln(x)
    • ln(1) = 0

5. Test-Taking Tips for Logarithms

  • Master the conversion between logarithmic and exponential form
    • This is THE most important skill for ACT logarithm questions
    • Practice until you can convert instantly without thinking
    • Almost every logarithm question becomes easy once you convert
  • Use your calculator with the change of base rule
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b) works for ANY logarithm
    • This lets you evaluate complex expressions quickly
    • Check if your calculator has a built-in logbase function
  • Backsolve when answer choices are given
    • Plug each answer choice into the original equation
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate on calculator
    • Often faster than using logarithm rules algebraically
  • Prioritize logarithm rules based on your target score
    • Target score below 28: Focus ONLY on conversion and change of base
    • Target score 28-32: Memorize the four logarithm rules
    • Target score 33+: Learn natural logarithms too
    • Don't waste time on rare topics if you need basics first!
  • Remember: logarithms are just another form of exponents
    • If you understand exponents well, logarithms become easier
    • The conversion is the bridge between the two
    • All logarithm rules mirror exponent rules

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Convert between forms: log_a(b) = c means a^c = b—this conversion solves almost all ACT logarithm questions
  • ✓Use change of base rule with calculator: log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b) to evaluate any logarithm quickly
  • ✓Memorize logarithm rules (product, quotient, power, log of 1) only if aiming for 30+—they appear rarely
  • ✓Natural logarithms (ln) use base e and follow the same conversion strategy: ln(b) = c means e^c = b

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Circles, Ellipses, and Hyperbolas
lessons.content:
Conic sections (circles, ellipses, and hyperbolas) appear 1-3 times per ACT Math test, usually focusing on the equation of a circle in standard form. Understanding how to identify the center and radius from the equation is the most important skill for these questions.

1. Equation of a Circle

  • Standard form of a circle (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r²
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Radius: r
  • Reading the center from the equation:
    • Example: (x - 3)² + (y + 5)² = 16 has center (3, -5)
    • Watch the signs! (x - h) means center x = +h, (y + k) means center y = -k
    • If (x - 3), the center x-coordinate is 3
    • If (y + 5), the center y-coordinate is -5 (opposite sign!)
  • Finding the radius:
    • r² is on the right side of the equation
    • Example: (x - 2)² + (y - 1)² = 25 has r² = 25, so r = 5
    • Example: (x + 1)² + (y - 3)² = 100 has r² = 100, so r = 10
    • Don't forget to take the square root!
  • Special case - circle centered at origin:
    • x² + y² = r²
    • Center: (0, 0)
    • Example: x² + y² = 49 is centered at origin with radius 7
  • Writing the equation when given center and radius:
    • Center (3, -2) and radius 5: (x - 3)² + (y + 2)² = 25
    • Center (-4, 7) and radius 6: (x + 4)² + (y - 7)² = 36
    • Remember to square the radius!

2. Completing the Square for Circles

  • Sometimes circle equations are given in expanded form:
    • Example: x² + 4x + y² - 8y + 5 = 0
    • This doesn't look like standard form!
    • You must complete the square to find center and radius
  • Steps to complete the square:
    • Step 1: Group x terms and y terms: (x² + 4x) + (y² - 8y) = -5
    • Step 2: For x terms, take half of coefficient of x, square it: (4/2)² = 4
    • Step 3: For y terms, take half of coefficient of y, square it: (-8/2)² = 16
    • Step 4: Add these to both sides: (x² + 4x + 4) + (y² - 8y + 16) = -5 + 4 + 16
    • Step 5: Factor: (x + 2)² + (y - 4)² = 15
    • Now you can read center (-2, 4) and radius √15
  • Quick formula for completing the square:
    • For x² + bx, add (b/2)²
    • This creates a perfect square: (x + b/2)²
    • Same process for y terms

3. Ellipses and Hyperbolas (Basic Recognition)

  • Ellipse standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² + (y - k)²/b² = 1
    • Center: (h, k), just like a circle
    • Looks like a stretched or compressed circle
    • Both terms are added (+), both squared
    • Example: (x - 2)²/9 + (y + 1)²/4 = 1 is centered at (2, -1)
  • Hyperbola standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² - (y - k)²/b² = 1 or (y - k)²/b² - (x - h)²/a² = 1
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Has two separate curved branches
    • Key difference: One term is subtracted (-)
    • Example: (x - 3)²/16 - (y + 2)²/9 = 1 is centered at (3, -2)
  • How to identify which conic section:
    • Circle: x² and y² have same coefficient, added together
    • Ellipse: x² and y² have different coefficients, added together
    • Hyperbola: x² and y² are subtracted
  • On the ACT:
    • Circles are tested most frequently
    • Ellipses and hyperbolas appear 0-2 times per test
    • Usually just need to identify center or general shape
    • Deep knowledge of ellipse/hyperbola properties rarely needed

4. Test-Taking Tips for Conic Sections

  • Master the circle equation first
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r² is the most tested formula
    • Practice reading the center until automatic
    • Remember: opposite signs! (x - 3) means center x = 3
  • Watch for completing the square questions
    • If the equation isn't in standard form, you'll need to complete the square
    • Take half the coefficient, square it, add to both sides
    • Don't forget to move the constant to the other side first!
  • Use the signs to identify the conic
    • Both terms positive (+)? Circle or ellipse
    • One term negative (-)? Hyperbola
    • This quick check eliminates wrong answers fast
  • Radius is always positive
    • r² = 25 means r = 5 (not ±5)
    • Radius cannot be negative in geometry
  • Memorize the standard forms
    • Circle: (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r²
    • Ellipse: (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1
    • Hyperbola: (x-h)²/a²-(y-k)²/b²=1
    • These formulas are NOT provided on the test

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Circle equation (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r² with center (h,k) and radius r—watch the signs! (x-3) means center x=3, (y+5) means center y=-5
  • ✓To complete the square for x²+bx, add (b/2)² to create a perfect square (x+b/2)²
  • ✓Identify conics by signs: both terms positive = circle/ellipse, one term negative = hyperbola
  • ✓Focus on circles first—they appear most frequently on the ACT, while ellipses and hyperbolas are rare

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.1 - Working Backwards Strategy
lessons.content:
The working backwards strategy is one of the most powerful time-saving techniques on the ACT Math section, letting you test answer choices instead of solving algebraically. This strategy works on 8-12 questions per test—that's 13-20% of all math questions!

1. What Is Backsolving?

  • Backsolving means plugging answer choices into the problem to find which one works
    • Instead of setting up equations and solving for x, you test each choice
    • Transforms complex algebra into simple arithmetic
    • Works by substituting values until you find one that satisfies all conditions
  • Key advantages over traditional algebra:
    • Often faster than setting up and solving complex equations
    • Less likely to make calculation errors with concrete numbers
    • Can verify your answer immediately
    • Works even if you struggle with algebra

When to Use Backsolving

  • Problem asks for a specific numerical value
    • "What is x?" or "How many marbles does Sarah have?"
    • NOT: "Which expression represents...?" or "What is the equation for...?"
  • Answer choices are concrete numbers, not algebraic expressions
    • ✓ Numbers like 2, 6, 14, 18, 22
    • ✗ Expressions like "2x + 3" or "a²b"
  • Traditional algebra looks messy or time-consuming
    • Complex equations with multiple steps
    • Radical expressions or absolute values
    • Situations with high error potential

2. The Strategic Backsolving Process

Step 1: Strategic Starting

  • Use the middle value strategy to maximize efficiency
    • ACT always lists answer choices in ascending or descending order
    • Begin with choice B or C (middle values)
    • If C is too big, eliminate D and E as well
    • If C is too small, eliminate A and B as well
    • This lets you eliminate 2-3 choices with one test

Step 2: Test Your Chosen Answer

  • Substitute the value into all problem conditions
    • Check: Does it make the equation true?
    • Check: Does it satisfy all constraints?
    • Check: Does it produce the correct result?

Step 3: If It Works, You're Done

  • Bubble in your answer and move on
    • Don't waste time double-checking or testing other choices
    • ACT only has one correct answer per question

Step 4: Eliminate and Adjust

  • If the answer doesn't work, cross it off immediately
    • Determine if you need a larger or smaller value
    • Use systematic elimination to rule out other choices
    • Use logic to narrow down remaining options

Step 5: Repeat

  • Test remaining choices systematically
    • Continue until you find the answer that works
    • Remember: exactly one of the five choices must work

3. Perfect Scenarios for Backsolving

  • Radical equations and square roots
    • Algebraically isolating variables requires squaring both sides multiple times
    • Creates opportunities for calculation errors
    • backsolving lets you test values directly in the original equation
  • Complex word problems
    • Multiple steps or complicated variable relationships
    • Test each answer against the problem's conditions
    • Helpful when you understand the question but struggle with setup
  • Systems of equations
    • Two or three equations with multiple variables
    • Often faster than elimination or substitution methods
    • Plug answer choices into all equations to find which satisfies them all

4. When NOT to Backsolve

  • Answer choices are algebraic expressions
    • Can't plug expressions like "2x + 3" or "n²" back into the problem
    • Must use traditional algebra to simplify and solve
  • Traditional algebra is very simple
    • Problems like "2x + 3 = 11, solve for x"
    • One or two steps of basic algebra is faster than testing choices
  • Testing takes more work than solving directly
    • Occasionally plugging in values requires more calculation than algebra
    • Use whichever method gets you to the answer fastest
  • Multiple variables with complex relationships
    • Many interconnected variables become confusing to test
    • Need to calculate multiple dependent values for each choice
    • Setting up equations systematically is often clearer

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Backsolving works by testing answer choices instead of solving algebraically—use when choices are numbers and algebra looks complex
  • ✓Always start with choice B or C to eliminate 2-3 options with one test using the middle value strategy
  • ✓Perfect for radical equations, complex word problems, and systems where algebra gets messy or time-consuming
  • ✓Avoid when answer choices are expressions, when algebra is simple, or when testing requires more work than solving

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Algebra Skills
lessons.content:
Core algebra skills appear on almost every ACT Math question, from simple equation solving to complex multi-step problems. Mastering PEMDAS, negative numbers, and combining like terms is essential for avoiding careless mistakes and solving problems quickly.

1. PEMDAS (Order of Operations)

  • PEMDAS is the order you MUST follow when solving expressions:
    • P - Parentheses: Complete calculations inside parentheses first
    • E - Exponents: Next, complete any exponents or square roots
    • MD - Multiplication and Division: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
    • AS - Addition and Subtraction: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
  • CRITICAL: Work left-to-right for MD and AS
    • This is where the ACT tricks students most often!
    • Example: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3
    • ✓ Correct: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3 = 4 × 2 - 3 = 8 - 3 = 5
    • ✗ Wrong: Don't do 4 × 2 first! That gives 16 ÷ 8 - 3 = -1 (incorrect)
  • Calculator shortcut:
    • Your calculator is programmed to follow PEMDAS automatically
    • Enter the expression exactly as written and let the calculator solve it
    • This prevents order of operations mistakes
    • Make sure to use parentheses when needed!
  • Common PEMDAS mistakes to avoid:
    • Doing multiplication before division (or vice versa) instead of left-to-right
    • Forgetting to complete parentheses first
    • Doing exponents after multiplication/division

2. Working with Negative Numbers

  • The ACT LOVES negative number questions—these are prime mistake opportunities
    • Students make more careless errors with negatives than any other topic
    • Take extra care and write out every step
  • Subtracting negative numbers:
    • Subtracting a negative = adding a positive
    • Example: 2 - (-4) = 2 + 4 = 6
    • Think: "minus a minus is a plus"
  • Distributing negative signs (HUGE mistake area):
    • You MUST distribute the negative to ALL terms in parentheses
    • Example: 5x - (2x - 5)
    • ✓ Correct: 5x - 2x - (-5) = 5x - 2x + 5 = 3x + 5
    • ✗ Wrong: 5x - 2x - 5 = 3x - 5 (forgot to distribute to the -5!)
    • The negative sign affects BOTH the 2x AND the -5
  • Negative numbers and exponents (another huge trap):
    • -x² is NOT the same as (-x)²
    • -x²: Square x first, then make it negative → -x² = -(x²)
    • (-x)²: Square the entire negative x → (-x)² = (-x)(-x) = x²
    • Example: -2² = -(2²) = -4
    • Example: (-2)² = (-2)(-2) = 4
    • Calculator tip: ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers!

3. Combining Like Terms

  • Like terms have the same variable raised to the same power:
    • 3x and 5x are like terms → can be combined to 8x
    • 2x² and 4x² are like terms → can be combined to 6x²
    • 3x and 5x² are NOT like terms → cannot be combined
    • Constants (numbers without variables) can always be combined
  • Steps for combining like terms:
    • Step 1: Distribute any parentheses
    • Step 2: Group like terms together
    • Step 3: Add or subtract the coefficients
    • Step 4: Simplify the expression
  • Example: 2(3x - 6) + 3y = 6x - y + 8, solve for y:
    • Distribute: 6x - 12 + 3y = 6x - y + 8
    • The 6x terms cancel on both sides
    • Simplify: -12 + 3y = -y + 8
    • Combine: 4y = 20
    • Solve: y = 5
  • When to combine like terms:
    • Always simplify equations before solving
    • Combining like terms reduces the equation to its simplest form
    • This makes it easier to see what to do next

4. Cross-Multiplying Fractions

  • When two fractions are equal, you can cross-multiply:
    • If x/y = z/w, then xw = yz
    • Multiply the numerator of each fraction by the denominator of the other
    • This eliminates the fractions and gives you a simpler equation
  • Visual representation:
    • x/y = z/w
    • Cross-multiply diagonally: x × w and y × z
    • Result: xw = yz
  • Example: If x/4 = 6/7, solve for x:
    • Cross-multiply: 7x = 4(6)
    • Simplify: 7x = 24
    • Solve: x = 24/7
  • When to use cross-multiplication:
    • When you have one fraction equal to another fraction
    • This is the fastest way to eliminate fractions
    • Much faster than finding common denominators

5. Test-Taking Tips for Algebra Skills

  • Write out every step—do NOT do mental math
    • Careless errors happen when you skip steps
    • Writing forces you to be careful with negative signs
    • You can check your work if you write it out
  • Use your calculator strategically
    • For PEMDAS problems: enter the entire expression
    • ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers
    • Double-check your calculator entry matches the problem
  • Circle or underline negative signs
    • Makes them more visible so you don't forget them
    • Especially important when distributing
  • Test your answer with substitution
    • If you solved for x, plug your answer back into the original equation
    • Does it make the equation true? Then you're correct!
    • This catches algebra mistakes
  • Master the basics before moving to advanced topics
    • These fundamental skills appear in EVERY algebra problem
    • You cannot do advanced algebra without mastering these basics
    • Practice until negative numbers and PEMDAS are automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Follow PEMDAS strictly, working LEFT TO RIGHT for multiplication/division and addition/subtraction—this is where most mistakes happen
  • ✓When distributing a negative sign, apply it to ALL terms: 5x - (2x - 5) = 5x - 2x + 5, not 5x - 2x - 5
  • ✓-x² ≠ (-x)²: without parentheses, square first then negate (-x² = -4 when x=2), with parentheses square the negative ((-x)² = 4)
  • ✓Write out every step and always use parentheses in your calculator for negative numbers—careless mistakes lose more points than not knowing the math

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Inequalities
lessons.content:
Inequalities appear 2-4 times per ACT Math test, testing your ability to solve algebraic inequalities and graph them on number lines or coordinate planes. The most important rule: flip the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

1. Solving Algebraic Inequalities

  • Treat inequality signs (<, >, ≤, ≥) like an equals sign:
    • Use all normal algebra rules: add, subtract, combine like terms
    • Isolate the variable just like solving equations
    • The inequality sign stays the same for most operations
  • CRITICAL RULE: Flip the sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative
    • This is the #1 mistake students make with inequalities!
    • Example: -2x + 5 < 11
    • Subtract 5: -2x < 6
    • Divide by -2: x > -3 (sign flipped from < to >!)
  • When NOT to flip the sign:
    • ONLY flip when you multiply or divide BOTH SIDES by a negative
    • Don't flip just because you see a negative number somewhere!
    • Example: 3x + 6 > x - 4
    • Combine: 2x > -10
    • Divide by 2 (positive): x > -5 (sign stays the same!)
  • Step-by-step process:
    • Step 1: Move all variable terms to one side
    • Step 2: Move all number terms to the other side
    • Step 3: Combine like terms
    • Step 4: Divide to isolate variable (flip sign if dividing by negative!)

2. Graphing Inequalities on a Number Line

  • Two types of circles on number lines:
    • Open circle (○): Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • The endpoint is NOT included in the solution
    • Example: x > 3 has an open circle at 3
    • Solid circle (●): Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • The endpoint IS included in the solution
    • Example: x ≥ 3 has a solid circle at 3
  • Which direction to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade to the RIGHT
    • Example: x ≥ 10/3 → solid circle at 10/3, shade right
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade to the LEFT
    • Example: x < -5 → open circle at -5, shade left
  • Quick memory trick:
    • The inequality sign "points" to the smaller values
    • So x > 3 means x is to the RIGHT of 3 (bigger values)
    • And x < 3 means x is to the LEFT of 3 (smaller values)

3. Graphing Linear Inequalities in the Coordinate Plane

  • Three-step process for graphing linear inequalities:
    • Step 1: Rearrange into y = mx + b form (slope-intercept)
    • Step 2: Plot the line (dashed or solid based on inequality)
    • Step 3: Shade the solution region (above or below the line)
  • Dashed vs. solid lines:
    • Dashed line: Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • Points ON the line are NOT part of the solution
    • Solid line: Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • Points ON the line ARE part of the solution
  • Where to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the line
    • Example: y ≥ 2x + 3 → solid line, shade above
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the line
    • Example: y < -x + 2 → dashed line, shade below
  • Example: Graph 2x + 3y ≥ 6
    • Step 1: Solve for y: 3y ≥ -2x + 6 → y ≥ (-2/3)x + 2
    • Step 2: Draw solid line (because of ≥)
    • Step 3: Shade above the line (because of ≥)

4. Systems of Inequalities and Advanced Graphing

  • Systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities on same graph):
    • Graph each inequality separately on the same coordinate plane
    • The solution is where the shaded regions OVERLAP
    • Example: y < 2x - 4 AND y > -(1/3)x - 2
    • Graph both lines, shade both regions, find the overlap
  • Parabola inequalities (follow same rules as lines):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the parabola
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the parabola
    • Use dashed curve for > and <, solid curve for ≥ and ≤
  • Circle and ellipse inequalities (different shading rules):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade OUTSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)² + (y-1)² > 4 → shade outside the circle
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade INSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)²/4 + (y-1)²/9 ≤ 1 → shade inside the ellipse
  • When you'll see advanced inequalities:
    • Parabola/circle/ellipse inequalities appear in the LAST 10 questions
    • These are for students aiming for 30+ scores
    • Master linear inequalities first before worrying about these!

5. Test-Taking Tips for Inequalities

  • Write "FLIP SIGN" when dividing by negatives
    • This is the most common mistake on inequality questions
    • Circle any negative you're dividing by to remind yourself
    • Double-check the final sign before selecting your answer
  • Use test points to check your graph shading
    • Pick a point in the shaded region (like (0,0) if it's not on the line)
    • Plug it into the original inequality
    • If it makes the inequality true, you shaded correctly!
    • If false, you shaded the wrong side
  • Remember: Open vs solid circles/lines
    • < and > → open circle/dashed line
    • ≤ and ≥ → solid circle/solid line
    • ACT answer choices often differ only in this detail!
  • For systems, look for the overlap
    • The solution to a system is where ALL shaded regions overlap
    • This is usually the darkest shaded area on the graph
    • Test a point in the overlap to verify it satisfies all inequalities
  • Circle/ellipse shading is opposite of parabola/line shading
    • Lines/parabolas: > means shade above
    • Circles/ellipses: > means shade outside
    • This catches many students—don't mix them up!

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓FLIP the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing BOTH SIDES by a negative number—this is the #1 mistake students make
  • ✓Number lines: use open circles for > and <, solid circles for ≥ and ≤; shade right for greater than, left for less than
  • ✓Linear/parabola inequalities: > and ≥ shade above the line, < and ≤ shade below; use dashed for strict (<, >), solid for inclusive (≤, ≥)
  • ✓Circle/ellipse inequalities shade OPPOSITE: > and ≥ shade OUTSIDE, < and ≤ shade INSIDE

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Number Substitution Technique
lessons.content:
Number substitution is a powerful test-taking strategy that transforms variable-heavy questions into simple arithmetic by plugging in concrete numbers. This technique works on 10-15% of ACT Math questions and is especially useful when you see multiple variables with few or no actual numbers!

1. What Is Number Substitution?

  • Number substitution means replacing variables with simple numbers to solve problems using arithmetic instead of complex algebra
    • Do you prefer working with numbers or variables? Most students prefer numbers!
    • Instead of manipulating algebraic expressions, you work with concrete values
    • Transform intimidating variable problems into straightforward arithmetic
  • Why this strategy is so powerful:
    • Questions with many unknown variables and few numbers often intimidate students
    • Working with real numbers is faster and less error-prone than abstract algebra
    • You can verify your answer immediately by checking it against the original problem
    • Works even if you struggle with complex algebraic manipulation

2. The 4-Step Substitution Process

Step 1: Pick Numbers for Variables

  • Choose simple, easy-to-work-with numbers
    • Avoid 0 and 1 — these can lead to incorrect answers that seem to work
    • Use 2, 3, 4, or 5 — small numbers that are easy to calculate with
    • Special cases: Use 10 for percent problems, 10 or 20 for group size problems
  • Select different numbers for each variable
    • If a question has x and y, pick x = 2 and y = 3
    • Using different values prevents confusion and ensures accurate results
  • Follow any rules stated in the question
    • If x must be negative and even, pick x = -2
    • If y must be greater than x, make sure your chosen values satisfy this
    • Pay attention to constraints like "positive integers" or "odd numbers"

Step 2: Write Down Your Numbers

  • Record your chosen values clearly
    • Write them in your test booklet or scratch paper
    • This prevents mistakes when plugging into answer choices
    • You'll need to reference these values multiple times

Step 3: Solve Using Your Numbers

  • Work through the question using your chosen values
    • Replace all variables with the numbers you picked
    • Calculate step-by-step using basic arithmetic
    • Find your numerical answer to the question

Step 4: Test Answer Choices
